Ottawa, December 19, 1947.

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Construction of new Day School,
Caradoc Reserve,

In memorandum dated November 10th, Mr. Pratt advised that Mr. Robert Dodds, Glencoe, Ontario, could supply and install a furnace for the above school.

We have just been advised by Indian Agent Down that Mr. Dodds is not prepared to supply and install the furnace that is required for this four-room school. In conversation with Mr. Down, Mr. Dodds expressed the opinion that it will be necessary to secure some firm from London to do the work.

As we are anxious to have the furnace installed as soon as possible so that the building may be heated and inside work continued, I would appreciate it if you could let me know the name of a firm in London who could be requested to give us a quotation.

[Signature]

PP. 60

Muncey, Ontario,
Dec. 16, 1947.

ATTENTION MR. NEAR

It is regretted that I find it necessary to again refer to tires for the school bus. I know, of course, that it is not your fault but I am, as usual, receiving the full force of criticism which rightly belongs elsewhere but, since coming to Muncey, I have certainly learned to accept unearned criticism.

I must advise, however, that I have exhausted all channels of emergency and, unless tires are produced immediately, I shall have but one alternative left - that is the discontinuance of the bus service. Everyone is becoming annoyed particularly the driver as he is continually on the road fixing tires. On account of the Christmas examinations our farm truck is standing idle because I have had to transfer the tires from it to the school bus. For such an important piece of equipment the ruling does seem strange. However, please understand I am not complaining but I must repeat, "If the tires do not soon arrive the bus service must, of necessity, be discontinued" which will, of course, mean that the pupils cannot get to school.

Yours truly,

Geo. W. Down,
SUPERINTENDENT.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Referring to the N School and our telephone conversation of December 1st.

Looking over the plan, I notice that there is no provision for eave-troughing which is perhaps overlooked. The building carries a large, fairly deep roof; in wet rainy weather the ground, particularly immediately under the eaves, would develop into mud holes and the water would perhaps find its way into the basement. Mr. Dods of Glencoe was on hand Tuesday and I had him submit an estimate covering a job on this building which is attached. You will note that the price covers 28 gauge material and labour complete, no extras or plus costs.

If accepted, the work can be proceeded with and finished within the present fiscal year.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

MEMORANDUM

DEPUTY MINISTER,

Re: New Day School on Caradoc Reserve, Electoral District of Middlesex, Province of Ontario.

In Mr. Pratt's memorandum of November 4th, 1947, we were advised that the Delaware Plumbing and Electric Company, Delaware, Ontario, should be invited to undertake the electrical wiring at the above school.

We received a reply reading as follows:

"Keyes and Dempsey will do work cost of materials plus 33% per cent plus labour costs."

On receipt of that communication we again communicated with the Agent with a view to obtaining the approximate total cost of doing the work on the basis mentioned above. We are now in receipt of the following information:

"I have been in constant touch with Mr. Dempsey of Delaware and he advises that he has made contacts with several electrical firms in the city of London and none will venture to give an approximate cost of any work. In these days of quotas, fluctuations and uncertainties he reports they are not even interested in work where estimates are required. Under the circumstances..."
Mr. Dempsey feels that he cannot commit himself and, if his offer to do the work on a material plus 3½ per cent plus labour cannot be accepted, he is not interested."

We would appreciate it if you would let us know your wishes in the matter.

PP/2CD

Director.

ATTENTION MR. HILL:

I wish to refer to our telephone conversation of a few days ago when you advised that the purchase of a new school bus had been assured, and that a Purchase Order would shortly be forwarded. In connection with this vehicle and other motor equipment I feel that it is my duty to point out the entire lack of garage accommodation. A new bus of this type should not be committed to the wide open spaces for a garage, and I feel that arrangements should be made to acquire a small piece of land and build the necessary buildings to accommodate two school buses and two trucks being operated for farm and general purpose use. Owing to the fact that general allotments may be insufficient for this year I would suggest that arrangements be made to have the land ready for building early in the 1948-49 fiscal year. Such a building might cost approximately $1,000.00 or $1,200.00 and might be shared equally between education and general welfare.

With regard to the land there is a plot of approximately 1½ acres, immediately adjacent to the Agency buildings, which I think could be purchased at a reasonable price. These are mere suggestions and submitted for your consideration.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Geo. W. Down,
S.M. INTENDANT.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.
Muncey, Ontario,
December 17, 1947.

Attention: Mr. Phelan

Confirming our telephone conversation re heating of New School.

In this connection I have contacted Mr. Dodds, of Glencoe, and he advises that he is not a hot water heating mechanic; and that his firm does not interest itself in hot water heating. He also advises that the building can be successfully heated by forced hot air, and that he would be interested in the job and would promise work to commence immediately. This however, would not entirely solve our problem as we still must have some plumbing work done which might be undertaken by Dempsey and Keayes of Delaware. This would keep the work all in the Riding as appears to be the Minister's wishes. Failing this Mr. Dodds again advises that hot water heating is a specialty and not all plumbers are capable of installing a complete job such as the one we have in mind, and the nearest firm that he knows of doing this type of work is in the city of London.

These are suggestions for your consideration but whatever the final outcome it is very important and very urgent. I would therefore request that no time be lost in arriving at a final decision and that I be advised as soon as possible.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept' of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA, Canada.

GWD/BC
Ottawa, December 23, 1947.

Nunney, Ontario.

Hot Water Heating - Mt. Elgin Indian Day School

Reference yours of December 17 -

We have noted Mr. Dodds' comments concerning hot air heating for this school. We have built this identical school elsewhere. Hot water heating systems have been definitely proven superior for heating and hence this type is specified. However, Mr. Dodds can submit a tender if you think it desirable.

We approached the Minister's office with regard to contractors for hot water heating. You are requested to approach the following two firms in London and request that they submit tenders:

1. Rhame Brothers, Limited,
   146 Worthly Road.

2. Eggett & Company,
   336 Rideout St.

Bernard F. Henry,
Dept. of Welfare & Training.

Re: New School Building Operations, Caradoc Agency

With reference to the above you are advised the funds on hand here to pay wages are down to around $400.00 so it is thought advisable to bring the matter to your attention in good time so that a further advance can be forwarded before we are out of funds.

The carpenters are working steadily and making reasonable progress considering the exceptionally cold weather and the lack of really adequate heating in such a large building; and the upper walls and ceiling are now covered with gyproc and they will shortly be engaged in placing in doors and hardware. It would be a good thing if the Department would arrange for an early delivery of the blackboards of which I spoke of on my recent visit to Ottawa.

The electrician has been somewhat slow in commencing work but from a conversation had with him yesterday it is expected he will start at the beginning of this week.

MEMORANDUM

Re: New Four Room Indian Day School,
Caradoc Agency, Province of Ontario.

In connection with Mr. Hoey's memorandum of February 9th bearing your notation of the 10th instant, together with attached tender prices and sketch layouts with reference to the stove, you are advised as follows:

The Rhame Bros. Limited, quotation of $1,359.00 for the plumbing installation is not unreasonable in consideration of present day prices and we would recommend that it be accepted.

The same firm quoted a price of $5,864.00 for a forced hot water heating system, based on the layout prepared by this Division for a similar school at Akasoni. It is our considered opinion that this price is fair and reasonable.

The forced warm air layout submitted by Robert Dodds, of Clencoe, Ontario, along with his quotation of $3,276.00 is lower than that submitted for the forced hot water system.

However, an analysis of the design brings to light several elements open to question and if it were revised and brought into line with present day accepted standards, the cost would be appreciably increased and the difference would, in our opinion, not be worth while.

It is our recommendation, therefore, that the forced hot water heating system based on our design for Akasoni, which we understand was used by Rhame Bros. Limited, in preparing their prices, should be installed in this school.

We are returning herewith tenders and sketch blueprints as requested.

(Signed) T.S. Mills,
Chief Engineer.

Memorandum:

MAJOR C.A.F. CLARK

Mount Elgin Indian Day School

This will confirm our conversation with regard to the above Day School. It would seem that relationships between the Principal and his staff are not what we would require and that it will be necessary for you to report upon conditions there in some detail. Apparently Mr. Johnston is not a good disciplinarian and, as a result, there is much freedom between the pupils and their particular teacher. Complaints have been made with regard to his association with the older girls. There is also evidence of too much freedom between the older boys and Mr. Johnston during recess and lunch hours. You can investigate these "stories" during your visit there and I wish to be advised as to whether we should contemplate the future employment of this teacher.

I would also like to know just how much teaching Mr. Joblin is doing. We are now paying four teachers at this school and I would like to know exactly what the teaching load of each teacher is. You might also check as to the number of visits which Mr. Joblin has made to the day schools of the agency.

The third point which I wish reported on is with respect to the contemplated construction of a one-room school at Rock Settlement. I would like a specific report from you as to where this new school can best be located. You can also investigate the question of land required for such a building. It will be our standard one-room school plan and I would suggest that you mail ahead a set of the plans, specifications and bill of materials for this project. I would like to have this school
constructed on a day labour basis, using the present foreman at the Mount Elgin Day School as the foreman for the one-room school. However, you can check into this matter with Colonel Randle when you are at Caradoc. It would be necessary to allow at least two months for requisitions to pass through the Departmental Purchasing Agent's hands and to arrive on the spot at Back Settlement. We would endeavour to rush the cement so that the excavation could be proceeded with.

Bernard F. Henry,
Superintendent of Education.
Muncy, Ontario,

Re: New School, Caradoc Agency

Your attention is drawn to the fact that when plans were made for the heating of the new school no one apparently gave any consideration to the installation of a stoker to be attached to the boiler. It is understood that a boiler of the type to be installed by the contractors should, to be economically and efficiently run, have a stoker rather than be fired by hand which would mean constant attention by the caretaker while in operation, and the use of a more expensive quality of coal.

Consequently it would appear beneficial all around to have a stoker installed while the contractors are there placing the heating system for the entire school; and we are advised by Rhame Brothers that they could supply and install a suitable automatic stoker, placed ready for operation, for $791.00.

May this Office please be advised if the Department will authorize such an expenditure, as evidently it is in the interest of efficient and economic heating of the new school.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dep't of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Colonel H. Neary, Superintendent of Education,
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Dear Colonel Neary:

While I have been going to Muncey some weeks now, - as my time there was somewhat limited most of the time was given to office matters, such as correspondence, interviews and general routine.

I did, of course, visit the new school each week to see how things were progressing, or discuss some angles with the foremen, - but not having much time assumed that as there were regular plans, everything was provided for.

Who drew up the plans I do not know, but since this week, having more time, there was an opportunity to go into things, - it appears to me there are some essential things not provided for, which in my opinion should be included.

For instance, there are four large class rooms, and in addition a manual training room and one for home economics. This means four teachers are there daily, and possibly two more, apart from the Supervising Principal, and yet there is no provision for a teachers' room where they can retire to when lessons are halted or to have lunch. This appears a great oversight to me, as they need rest and relaxation out of the schoolroom, as none of the children go home for lunch like an ordinary day school, so the teachers will get little privacy or rest.

Then while there appears to be one washroom provided evidently for the teachers, - if both sexes are there, as is likely, it would appear there should be two.

Then with regard to the children's toilets, - apparently the plans call for outside ones, with a septic tank serving both, - but actually, I understand,
(and quite rightly so) it is intended now to have them inside.

This may raise some structural difficulties, as the basement is below ground level quite a bit, and it appears they would have to be raised up to obtain proper operation of the septic tanks.

It also means there must be two septic tanks instead of one, - as the boys and girls could not now be arranged anywhere adjacent to each other, and as far as can be seen will have to be more or less at opposite ends, - which means one would have too long a flow to operate from one tank.

Also the provision of these toilets for the children will entail extra expense, as they were not in the plans, - and as the contract given to Hame Bros. for plumbing was based only on the original plans. I, of course, did not realize this at the time, for the reasons outlined at the beginning of this letter, and evidently no-one in Ottawa took it into consideration when the contract was being considered.

Personally, it is my opinion with the room there was available, had all these things been considered and planned from the start they could have been fitted in conveniently and suitably.

Now of course, it may be possible to place them in, - but it will cut things up in a far less suitable manner, and make for awkwardness, for while there is considerable space, it is now in the wrong locations.

You might please give this matter early thought and consideration, and actually I would prefer either you or Mr. Phelan to run down next Thursday or Friday and meet me there just to discuss these things on the spot, and see if we could not plan somehow to work in some of these essential needs, and the extra cost they would entail.

Lt.-Col.E.P.Randle,
Indian Superintendent.
New Caradoc School.

We, the undersigned, do hereby offer and agree to do the following:

EXTERIOR
To paint cornice, windows and doors, etc., three (3) coats of first grade exterior paint, any color.

INTERIOR
To paint ceilings and walls in four school rooms on first floor and ceilings and walls of two halls, three (3) coats of interior paint.

To stain all woodwork, doors, stairs, etc., and give the same two (2) coats of varnish.

To varnish all masonite in class rooms and halls three (3) times.

To paint all radiators aluminum.

BASEMENT
To paint ceilings and walls in basement classrooms with two (2) coats of paint.
To paint interior of all sash two (2) coats white paint.

To stain all woodwork, doors, window frames, etc., and give same two (2) coats of varnish.

To paint aluminum all radiators and exposed pipes.

The contractor to supply all materials, provide own scaffolding, and do all labor required to leave all the above specified work in a workmanlike manner and satisfactory to the Department's representative. All to be done for the sum of $1,850.00

Muncey, Ontario
June 28th, 1948

The Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

Re: Schools Caradoc Agency.

Since coming to Muncey I have had the opportunity to visit all the schools on the reserve except that one which is being replaced this year and known as the Back Settlement; a survey was made of the fabric of the buildings and the following are my recommendations for this summer.

Oneida #1:
The building needs painting inside as it is pretty dirty; there is about 2,000 sq. feet to be painted white and about 400 sq. feet to be painted a light tan; I am suggesting the latter in place of the prevalent green on the lower walls.

The Cistern in the girls washroom needs to be cleaned out as the run off from the tap is a mere trickle.

The cellar windows need to be checked and tightened up as they allow the water to enter during a storm.

A heavy wire screen should be placed over the windows at the south side of the school so that there will be less danger of being broken by the pupils playing ball.

Apparently some mention has been made of getting hydro into this school, as the line is close I would recommend that this be proceeded with; it will be necessary to have an entrance cut in to the attic to facilitate the installation.

Oneida #2:
Inside needs painting, the area will be about 1,800 sq. feet white and 400 sq. feet light tan, to be given two coats.

The Blackboard on the side wall to be painted, and that at the end of the room to be repaired.

A cupboard that can be locked should be built.
that supplies of stationery etc. may be kept inside instead of in the entrance as at the present time.

The outside paint and the roof are in fair condition.

5 new window blinds are needed, I would suggest that they be cream in colour, size 36" by 72" in length.

The heater is getting to be old and is small, and I am of the opinion that a new larger heater, circulator type, with a screen should be provided.

Outside steps need to be replaced, 3 pieces of lumber 2"x10"x7 feet will be required for this job.

The pump handle needs to be replaced.

Oil is used on the floors which results in anything that touches the floor being dirty; I think they would be better if after washing they were given a couple of coats of Deck lac or some other preparation that will give a clean, bright finish.

The teacher's desk is old and worn out, it should be replaced also two chairs be provided.

This school is also near a Hydro line and if at all possible it should be installed.

Oneida #1.

The outside is in pretty good shape.

Inside needs painting, an area of 2,000 sq. feet and 400 sq. feet will need two coats, the former white and the latter a light tan.

A furnace has been installed here, the old stove and pipes need to be removed.

New window blinds are needed, 6 Cream blinds 36"x96" will do this.

2 outside locks are needed for the outside door and that door leading to the basement.

Bear Creek.

The inside needs painting, the area to be covered is about 1,300 sq. feet in white and 400 sq. feet in a light tan.......
Bear Creek painting contd.—two cents will be needed to do a good job.

The heater is in poor condition, and I would recommend a new larger heater be supplied.

The casing of the door should be repaired as at the present time it is very drafty during the winter and has to be stuffed with mats etc.

The floor at the entrance needs to be taken up and a new one laid, the area of this piece is about 8' x 8'.

The teacher at this school, Miss Arnott wishes to return to the same school.

River Settlement:

I understand that a proposition has been made to close this school and transfer the pupils to the Mount Elgin Continuation school, this appears to be both feasible and wise, the schools are fairly close together, and the old school is in pretty bad shape, in fact I would say that a new school is needed if we wish to continue at the same site.

The enrollment at this school will be about 22 to 25 for the 1948-49 year.

General:

No doubt you have already had reports from the education supervisors regarding the schools here, but I will give you my impressions.

The new Mount Elgin school is coming along pretty good and ought to be finished in good time.

A change of the Hydro lead in will be necessary before the old residential school is torn down, so that the lead in will be to the annex, being used for classes at the present time, but which will probably be used for teacher accommodation for some time yet.

There is an electric stove in the residential school, where was this intended for? It was placed there in 1947, I have just found out that it is an old stove which was removed from the home of Mr. Down when a new one was purchased last year, it is not in good enough shape to be used for Home economics.

There is a large blanket loom in the old school also, there is apparently no intention of using it here so I would suggest it be transferred to some other school in the near future.
Mr. Jgblin mentioned the possibility of finding a position as teacher for Mrs. Ruben Schuyler, who is apparently the only qualified Indian teacher from this reservation. I think the idea is sound; it would act as an incentive to other young people on the reserve to endeavour to improve their own chances of getting a position with the Branch.

The reports on Miss Morris are not very encouraging for the older pupils; she appears to be good with the junior forms but poor with the senior forms. I understand that none of the older pupils will graduate this year.

I have had some conversation with Miss Mrs. Harledge regarding a telephone account; the matter is partially settled but an amount of about $6.50 is still outstanding. I am seeing the telephone people some time this week and will try to get it cleared up. I do not think the this lady should be allowed to return to the agency; her influence has been quite upsetting and is obvious before you have been here a few hours. She is in Montreal at the present time, and I would recommend that she be interviewed in Ottawa and either placed elsewhere or her services be dispensed with. It is going to be hard for the new superintendent here under any circumstances and any source of friction ought to be removed.

No arrangements were made last year of goods to provide the children with a hot lunch; this should be rectified and either an amount of money made available or the superintendent advised to requisition for the supplies needed.

All the lawns are in poor shape, untidy and long grass; it would improve the whole set up if these could be kept in better shape and help to inculcate neatness among the pupils.

The water coolers are being collected to be stored at the agency building; the new bus is being put up for the holidays, but it will be necessary to use the old one for some time transporting materials for repair work.

The janitor ought to have a tool chest with a supply of the necessary tools for general repairs; I would suggest that Mr. Doucett be asked to make a list of the tools that might be needed.

The requisitions for supplies for next year are being collected and mailed to you as they arrive.
I have made the recommendation in the earlier part of this report that the colours of the paint inside the classrooms be changed to White and Light tan for the lower part of the walls, I think this would be an improvement on the present green and white or cream and green as they are painted at present.

Has the question of heating the schools with oil ever been brought up; I think it would be more economical here and give a better range of heat control.

The old school bus which was secured from War Assets is not in very good shape, in fact it is in need for repairs to the radiator, it was blocked and the last day of school could be only be driven a few miles at a time due to it boiling; a requisition is being sent in for a set of wrenches for this truck, it is apparently different from the general run as it was a converted army truck.

I realize the above report is very lengthy, but I thought it was necessary as much of this work will have to be initiated from Ottawa during the interim until a new superintendent is appointed, the most urgent thing at the moment is a set of tools and authority to purchase or an order placed for paint and brushes.

Yours very truly

F. Matters
Regional Supervisor.
Muncey, Ontario,
June 30, 1945.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Re: Middlesex - Mount Elgin Res. School

I am enclosing a list of articles purchased or taken over by the Department from the Mount Elgin Indian Residential School, and should be glad if you would look into the matter and give us an idea of how much we should get for these articles which are not priced. We have already received payment for the Chevrolet truck.

With regard to the sewing machine, it is a small machine and I think it should be worth $25.00.

As far as the work tables and chairs in the sewing room are concerned, I shall leave you and Mr. Phelan to put a price on these.

We shall make no charge for the articles left in the library.

With regard to the crosscut saws and other articles which were left around the farm and buildings, I think we should get something for these, but I am not sure how much they are worth, except the 25 tons of stoker coal. This is coal which you are now using and which you would have had to purchase.

We shall also be glad if you will put a price on the power tools in the manual training shop, which I understand were purchased by Mr. Strapp.

We shall appreciate your giving this matter your attention.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Memorandum

Re: Mount Elgin School.

When visiting the Caradoc Agency on the 22nd and 23rd of May, Mr. Arneil, Indian Agent Downie, and myself, discussed what should be done with the present Mount Elgin School, when the new school is completed.

Mr. Downie suggested that we should remove the two top floors, leaving the ground floor of the building and use this partly for a recreational centre for the Indians, the balance for meetings of home makers clubs, etc.

My own opinion is, it would be a very expensive proposition to carry out Mr. Downie's suggestion, and when the work is completed, we would only have an old building, very difficult to heat, and likely, almost impossible to keep clean.

Mr. Downie has already had inquiries from wrecking firms wishing to quote a price on tearing down the building.

I feel very definitely that when the new school is completed, the old school should be demolished.

No doubt, a recreation centre for the Indians would be very advisable, and possibly it should be located on the site of the present Mount Elgin School, but I believe that a new building erected for this purpose would not cost as much as it would to endeavour to renovate the present building, and would be much more satisfactory.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Mount Elgin Indian Residential School

The attached files concern the main building formerly occupied by students attending the Mount Elgin Residential School.

In 1926, when this building was erected, various Indian bands that were served by the school contributed $10,000.00 from their funds towards the capital expenses. Since that time, the Department has expended from Parliamentary Appropriation for buildings and improvements a sum in excess of $130,000.00.

In 1915 fire destroyed some of the outbuildings and pursuant to the collection of insurance $7,500.00 was repaid to the band funds leaving an equity of only $11,000.00.

This school building was condemned two years ago and is no longer in use by the Department or by the Indians. We have erected a new day school a short distance away and intend opening this school during the summer of 1948. We are still continuing to use the separate classroom block of the old school.

It has been recommended that this old main building (not the separate classroom block) be declared surplus and turned over to our Assets Corporation as surplus government property. Proper insulation is perhaps the best solution to any heating problem. STELOX Buildings are adaptable to standard forms of insulation and we recommend that the following practice be followed:

During recent visits to the schools I was approached by teachers as to the possibility of first aid kits. Such kits, at one time, were a regular piece of equipment of all our schools but the practice seems to have been dropped. Former Mount Elgin Indian Residential School Building -

The attached files concern the main building formerly occupied by students attending the Mount Elgin Residential School.

In 1896, when this building was erected, various Indian bands that were served by the school contributed $19,000.00 from their funds towards the capital expense. Since that time, the Department has expended from Parliamentary Appropriation for buildings and improvements a sum in excess of $130,000.00.

In 1925 fire destroyed some of the outbuildings and pursuant to the collection of insurance $7,400.00 was repaid to the band funds leaving an equity of only $11,600.00.

This school building was condemned two years ago and is no longer in use by the Department or by the Indians. We have erected a new day school a short distance away and intend opening this school during the summer of 1948. We are still continuing to use the separate classroom block of the old school.

It has been recommended that this old main building (not the separate classroom block) be declared surplus and turned over to War Assets Corporation as surplus government property. The point at issue is whether we have the authority to do this, in view of the Indians' equity in these buildings.

Attention - Mr. G.N. Weekes

Dear Sir:

Former Mount Elgin Indian Residential School

I have for answer your letter of July 23rd and your telegram of July 28th concerning the above school buildings and the property on which they are located.

The school buildings are located not on the 200 acres described in Surrender 58C but on the 4 acres described in Surrender 58B, copy of which is attached. Both these Surrenders were signed on February 13th, 1849. At the same time, Surrenders 58D and 58E were signed.

The dormitory block of the old school, erected by the Canadian Wesleyan Methodist Conference and Missionary Society was destroyed by fire. In 1896 the Department built another dormitory block in order that a residential school could be continued at Mount Elgin.

A few years ago, this block was condemned by Departmental Engineers as it was in a condition dangerous to the school children. It was found that the brick arches were flattening and dislodging brick along
the underside of the arch. This loosening was caused by the settlement of the building at the north end, thus removing the lateral support over the arches. Before building another dormitory block, it was decided to have a thorough educational survey made to determine the type of educational facilities which would best serve the Caradoc Indians.

This survey was made by a Provincial School Inspector and by the Reverend E.E.M. Joblin, M.A., of the United Church of Canada (now supervising principal of the Caradoc Schools). Acting upon the recommendations made in this survey, it was decided to close the Mount Elgin Residential School and to open a new consolidated day school.

Action was immediately taken to begin the erection of a four-room consolidated school completely modern in every respect. This building is now practically finished. It is situated near the old residential school buildings.

We have provided two school buses both in charge of qualified Indian drivers. The children are transported daily to and from the consolidated school. A competent staff of qualified teachers has been conducting classes up to Grade I in the old classroom block. These classes will, of course, be conducted next year in the new building.

The Reverend Mr. Joblin who has an M.A., in Education from the University of Toronto, has been appointed Supervising Principal and is concerned with the work of the day schools and the new consolidated school. He has the confidence of the two Provincial School Inspectors who visited the schools of the reserve and they have both expressed their pleasure at the manner in which progress is being made in our educational system at Caradoc.

In a report dated May 20, 1948, School Inspector Young made the following comments:

"As the experiment advances, we see more and more benefits coming to the Indian Young People by reason of our policy. In the wider field of supervision of the Senior School, I think that Mr. Jolin has done a splendid piece of work."

We realize the need for agricultural instruction for these young Indians. At the present time we are negotiating with a qualified teacher who is a young veteran and a graduate of the Ontario Agricultural College, and hope to add him to our Caradoc teaching staff next year.

In view of the condemnation of the old dormitory block erected by the Department and the building of a new school, it was decided to declare this building surplus and to request War Assets Corporation to have it demolished.

You will note that we have not declared surplus the old classroom block or so-called Annex Building. This was erected in 1931 and enlarged in 1956. It contains three classrooms and living quarters for the teaching staff.

With regard to the 200 acres of land in Surrender 360, it was the intention to operate a model community welfare farm to be farmed by the Indians for the benefit of the aged and indigent Indians and for the instruction of young Indians in farming methods and techniques. Because of the lack of a farming instructor and the illness of former Superintendent Down, it was decided to delay this project until a new Superintendent and farming instructor were appointed.

A farming instructor is now at Caradoc and the Civil Service Commission is advertising for a
new Superintendent. Therefore, it is our intention, in due course, to discuss these proposals with the Caradoc Indian Council.

You will find that Section II of the Indian Act refers to the taking of lands for school purposes.

Re: Purchase of New Desks for Caradoc Continuation School

This is in reply to your letter of October 30, 1948 under file 468-5-(E.1).

The decision to request 100 new desks and also 4 new teacher's desks and four teacher's chairs was made jointly by Mr. J. E. Morris, Regional Supervisor, Mr. E.M. Joblin, Principal, and myself. We felt that 140 desks were needed in the new school of which 40 could be secured from the old school.

To-day I was in contact again with Mr. Joblin and we feel that if the Department would be willing to replace the same next year that an additional 25 seats could be transferred from the old school for temporary use but the others in use at present, we believe, should be discarded. Many of them are double seats.

It would be unfair to the teachers to ask them to continue using the present desks.

We trust this will clarify the matter.

Yours truly,

Fred Hall,
Superintendent.

Re: Desks for Caradoc Continuation School

This Office is unfamiliar with the policy of the Department as to equipment for new schools. However, it seems to us, and we believe it was the opinion of Mr. Morris and Mr. Joblin, that the rooms should be properly equipped. The rooms are of a size to accommodate approximately 35 pupils, hence we requested 140 desks for the four rooms.

No doubt you are aware of the increase in enrolment in these schools as the season progresses, therefore the October enrolment is not necessarily a true picture of the situation.

With the requests of Mr. Morris and Mr. Joblin, and our previous correspondence in your hands along with our opinions expressed herein, we would suggest you send the desks deemed proper by the Department.

As to the date on which the school can be opened, it is difficult to say. It has been two years or more since commencement of building and it seems difficult to get the necessary supplies to complete the plumbing. However, we hope to open by January 1, 1949.

Yours truly,

Fred Hall, Supt.
November 30, 1948.

Mr. Fred Hall,
Superintendent,
Indian Agency,
Muncey, Ontario.

We have your letter of the 23rd instant with further reference to desks for the new Caradoc School.

As intimated in official letter of November 13th, we feel that if forty-five new desks are supplied at the present time, it should be sufficient to meet the requirements until after the end of the present fiscal year at least.

Our funds are limited and consequently we do not wish to purchase more desks than are actually needed between now and the end of March.

We intend to supply single chair desks and they are made in three sizes, namely, large, medium and small. Please let me know the number of each size that you require to make the total of forty-five new desks.

Bernard T. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

December 2, 1948.

Mr. K.L. Hall,
Superintendent, Caradoc Indian Agency,
Manitoulin Island, Ontario.

Mount Elgin Indian Day School,

Mr. McCubbin, M.P., visited this office yesterday and discussed plans for the opening of the new Mount Elgin School. He is going to try to interest the Minister in visiting your agency on this occasion so that he might officially open the new building.

As soon as we receive definite information as to whether the Minister will accept this invitation, we will write you further. Mr. McCubbin has suggested that the official opening be held in the evening and that a small dance be held after the ceremonies are finished. At official openings in the past, the programme has usually fallen into three main parts:

(1) A short concert by school children, accompanied by display of work.

(2) Official opening ceremonies and short address by the Minister.

(3) Refreshments and social evening.

I would like to suggest that you discuss this matter at some length with your Supervising Principal and let me have your comments in the near future as to the type of programme and probable cost of putting on such a short entertainment.

Bernard T. Henry,
Superintendent of Education.

This is in reply to your letter dated March 1, 1949 wherein you state that the purchase price of the house ($250.00) was paid to the Chippewa Band Fund Trust Account & Co. I presume that the same has been done with regards to the house sold to Master Hendrick.

I am curious to know upon what authority or for what reason this money was paid into the Band Funds. The fact that the house is situated on what was Band land has been established. However, I believe that it is an undisputed fact that both houses were built for the use of employees of the Mt. Elgin Residential School. It would seem that the money for the construction of these houses was provided by either the Department or the Church or by both. Most definitely it was not provided from Band Funds.

In view of these facts I feel that the houses were intended for the benefit of the school. Our present school is
carrying on in the place of the Residential School and should inherit to some degree what had been bestowed upon the latter by both the Department and the Church. Besides, the Band as well as the other Bands of this Reserve will benefit from the improvements in the grounds and surroundings of the New School whereas money into the Band Fund cannot possibly radiate such broad benefits.

For the above stated reasons I would ask that the decision to pay this money into Band Funds be reconsidered and that instead it be paid to the Office so as need to improve the grounds and surroundings of the New Mt. Elgin Indian Day School.

Yours truly,

Fred Hall,
SUPERINTENDENT.

Re: Money for Hot Lunches at Mt. Elgin Day School

Thus far it has been impossible to provide hot lunches for the pupils of this school because there are no stoves, hot plates or other cooking equipment. However, it has been the custom for many of the pupils to purchase a pint bottle of chocolate milk for the mid-day meal. This milk is delivered daily at the school at a cost of 5¢ per bottle.

Mr. Joblin states that the children bring good lunches, come to school in heated buses and are housed in a comfortable building. Unfortunately many of them do not drink milk at home, hence this opportunity to provide them with milk seems to be well worth taking advantage of. We thought that the grant toward hot lunches might be used to subsidize the purchase of milk and thus aid in seeing that each child receives a just share throughout the year.

Your comments on this proposal will be appreciated.

Chocolate Milk Sale Ended,
Education Official Declares

Sale of chocolate milk in Toronto, Ont., "But that doesn't mean there isn't any," he added.

Mr. Conquest said the board had given the question thorough consideration at several meetings in the spring, that decided to take no action at present but would consider it again, he said.

Advisability of selling the drink in schools was debated earlier this week by the Board's Nutrition Committee, which decided not to buy for school children.

The question of chocolate milk brought out at this meeting was discussed by the school board in this city last night. They decided to consider the question because the milk had been harmed in Montreal and London, Ont., schools.

Report on equipment, in reply to letter from Mr. Phelan

Vocational Training: Boys. Materials not on hand, and work going forward on cupboards. Classes now being held in new building.

Girls. Materials of purchase order arriving. Negotiations under way for kitchen cupboard. Separate letter forthcoming re Home Economics cottages. May be other smaller ones required when we know what has been ordered.

Small items needed: - Mirrors, 1 large for girls' washroom, 1 for boys'.

- Smaller ones for each of two teachers' wastebaskets, 1 quite large in each of rooms the two pupils' washrooms, for paper towels, etc.

- 2 medium size, for large basement rooms, for lunch papers, etc.

Clocks, some type of small clock for each of the four classrooms.

Electric bell with transformer and button. For half-hour bells throughout the day. Have one, need second for basement.

Furniture: Teachers' desks. 1 new desk just arrived. Now have two good desks, another one needed. Not urgent, but should be replaced to match new pupils' desks as they arrive.

Pupils' desks. Received 45 new type desks. Should add to these at least 30 more at cost of $25 per set. Not using old desks in two rooms. Some old two-pupil desks. Need 25 new desks, large size now. Could then let an occasional one go when needed in outside schools.

Teachers' rest rooms. Ladies', at least a comfortable chair and bed desirable. No space long enough for a cot.

Mens', table and chair

Folding chairs or benches for 100 persons for basement auditorium

Blackboards for basement are here, need only to be put up.

Bookshelves are being made by pupils. Are open shelves, and dusty. One enclosed bookcase in each room would prove very acceptable.

No word yet about the usual grants for shop, Home Economics, Visual Aids.

No word yet about requisition for science materials. Crafts.
Muncy, Ontario,

to our disadvantage is not to us a matter of surprise, for it is not the first time. The Department has always been our protector when any encroachment has been attempted.

It is only a few years since the Department was petitioned to have the roadway west side of the farm proper enlarged by taking about 4 rods off the farm from the North to the South. On investigation by Agent Dingman it was ordered that there be no change. We had hoped then that matters were settled for all time to come. Since then at large expense we have gravelled the roads and renewed fences making things permanent.

We are sure that the Department before consenting to any change from the original bounds fixed by a properly authorized survey in 1864, when this was comparatively a wilderness, will consider the strength of our claim, and the manner in which the land has been used to a great extent of cultivation.

One of the reasons assigned for the re-survey is the supposition that we have more than the 264 acres. But according to our own measurement we have not, but let that be as it may. If the new survey had shown that we had less than the 264 acres we would simply have been referred to our title, which calls for 264 acres more or less. At the same time if the new survey is correct and if we have more than the 264 acres does not our title allow it?

Again a glance at the map of the new survey will show you that it takes off a large strip of the North side of the farm. This strip includes our Carpenter and Shoe shop, lumber shed, Recreation Hall and one farm residence together with nearly all the boy's play grounds. All of which has always been re-
marked as the property of the Institution with the exception of a road way leading to the ford and what is called the Walnut park sloping from that road down to the river about 2 acres. Would the Society and would the Department have authorized the erection of these buildings on said land if not included in our title?

I want to just here speak of what I think led to a mistake in the new survey. It is this, the river is constantly encroaching upon the Walnut park so much so that nearly half the amount has gone away in our 16 years. How much it has changed since 1847 until our time we cannot just say but the bed of the river has changed at least 50 ft. in the 16 years. This slide has necessitated moving the road at top of the hill leading to the ford back on the boy's play-ground. So that the second fence has had to be removed in 10 years. The mistake seems to me to have been made by the survey taking a point as far back from the river bank as the one that was taken in 1849, while the river in that time must have moved some 75 ft.

You ask what concessions we would be willing to make in order to satisfy the Indians. I have not had any conversation with the Indians touching this new survey with the exception of Chief John Henry, whom I consulted privately since receiving your letter of March 23rd—to find out what led up to the new survey and how far the Indians were dissatisfied with the present boundaries of the Institution farm. He says the Indians are not dissatisfied, but that the agitation for the re-survey was brought on just before the local elections for chief, by one who was then a member of the council and was ambitious to be elected Head Chief and thought this scheme...
of curtailing the Institution property would make him popular with the band and secure his election. The other councilors did not like to oppose it on the eve of an election for fear of their seats and it carried by a small majority. Now Mr. Henry says the proof that the Indians are not dissatisfied is seen in that they did not elect that man as chief, nor give him any official position in the council.

In regard to making any concessions to the Indians. The road for the present will have to be continued with gates though it is moved in on the Institution property from where it was. The prospect is that in a short time a bridge will be built connecting the two reserves. It is now being agitated and will be either on the reserves or adjacent to them when built this road may profitably be closed up. The Walnut park never did belong to us but has been used by the Institution and could not well be used by any body else as the Institution has a Government lease of the land across from it and it is included in that as a pasture. The most they could expect is rent for the 2 acres which is not worth the name.

The fence is not on the line of the 23 acre piece across the road from the Institution proper. Whoever built the fence took in about an acre more than belongs to use. The fence should be rebuilt and it is my intention to put it on the line where it should be some time this fall.

There can be no question but that the river on the North and East after you pass the little park and the ford for Ovide was intended to be the boundary in that direction and the road on the West side of the farm proper the boundary in that direction. So that the only thing remaining is the slight excess in the 22.5 acre field and that on the North we hope
to correct as before stated.

Hoping that you will deem it advisable to pronounce this settled for all time to come I am

most respectfully yours,

MEMORANDUM.

Ottawa 13th October, 1897.

The survey made by Mr. Green of the lands of the Mohawk Institute, which survey was made at the request of the Indians, showed that the Reserve occupies a strip of land along the River Thames containing 27 Acres in excess of the lands rightfully held by the Institute under Surrenders taken many years ago.

The Institute has been in occupation of the said strip of land for over 50 years.

The Principal, Mr. Shepherd, thinks that there is no excess of land held by the Institute, but that the said excess constitutes what was formerly a tow-path along the river.

Mr. Shepherd is in error on this point, as a tow-path would not occupy 1/4 of the said area of 27 Acres.

The said strip is a steep side hill for almost the entire distance. It is very probably that the said side hill was considered, at the time of the original survey, to be of little or no value, and the boundary of the Institute's lands was then defined along the top of the bank, and not along the edge of the river.

The Indians have made no request that the said land should be vacated by the Institute, and it appears that only a small portion of the said strip could be utilized by them, but after a request made to them, they have decided that they will not surrender the land, in order that it may be legally occupied by the Institute.

It would evidently be a great hardship to compel the Institute to vacate this land, this new date.
Under the circumstances, it might be advisable to simply let the matter drop, but as a feeling of unrest and dissatisfaction would continue, I would recommend that Mr. Shepherd be informed that the Department does not at present intend to take away the use of this strip of land from the Institute, but that he should endeavour to arrive, as soon as possible, at a satisfactory arrangement with the Indians, in order to place the matter on a proper footing.

Mr. Shepherd should also be informed that he should place the fences of the Institute on the correct lines, as soon as this may be conveniently done.

I would also recommend that the Indians be informed through their Agent, that the Department regrets that they have refused to make the desired Surrender, and that in view of the fact that the Institute has been long in occupation of these lands, it would be unjust and unfair to take this land from the Institute, and would therefore advise them to come to some mutually satisfactory understanding regarding the matter, with the Principal, Mr. Shepherd.
Ottawa 15th October, 1897.

Reverend Sir,

Referring to your letter of the 3rd August last regarding the re-survey of the lands held by the Mount Elgin Institute, I have to inform you that the tow-path, to which you refer, would not occupy one quarter of the area of 37 acres, held in excess by the Institute.

This excess, as I believe, consists principally of a wooded area. It was therefore probably not included in the original survey of the Institute Lands. The boundary along this portion was probably laid out on top of the bank instead of along it.

The Department has decided not to take any action at present to dispossess the Institute of the occupation of this land, but I have to request you to come to some mutually satisfactory arrangement with the Indians, in order that the matter may be put on a proper footing.

Dear Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter dated April 27th, in which you ask for receipt for certain funds as per attached business statement. These receipts are on hand, some are paid. Some of these business matters can be settled in this way by payment. If paid all at once and not in receipt, we can settle it up properly so they would have to pay it again or settle it their way.

For instance—

Katherine Spencer is a woman whose husband died leaving her. She is old and unable to work. Dec. 1st 1916 she cashed which was $35.00 per annum was $40.00 unpaid. She gave her $20.00 and placed her rent deposit with a total of $20.00 so much of her rent she has already been paid. Besides this she has also received $20.00 on May 1st, $20.00 on May 15th, $20.00 on May 25th, $20.00 on May 31st, and $20.00 on June 1st.

In medical attendance during her illness she was paid $20.00. Of course this is not business but it is necessary.

She has been able to go back to work since she was able to find work. She has helped by giving many of her children the help she needs from time to time. She has a lot of small children—her sick and families. I gave them through Mr. Agent further.

Dear Sir:

Government Lease #316 covering lands from which this school draws its water supply expires April 1st, 1933.

Mr. Agent Moore and I called upon the present lessee a few days ago releasing the land. He is a little "queer" and would not give us any satisfaction. We really must have the water, and the only way to make sure of it is to control the land and preserve the bush covering the springs.

Ottawa, January 21st, 1935.

MEMORANDUM:

Rev. Williams,

The Department has certain Indian lands leased on the Caradoc Reserve for the use of the Mount Elgin Institute under leases No. 356 and 356. Lease No. 356 will expire on April 30th and 356 on March 31st.

These leases issued some 20 years ago provide for a renewal term upon terms to be agreed upon. The lands covered by these leases are absolutely indispensable to the School as the only water supply for the buildings comes from these lands and a great deal of money has been expended in piping the water to the School.

The owner of the land, Louis McGahey, covered by lease 356, apparently does not want the Institute to have this land again. I saw him personally and tried to make arrangements for another term at an increased rental but failed. He is very antagonistic towards the Reverend Principal of the School and expressed himself as preferring to let the land lay idle rather than let the Institute have it.

He complains that the Rev. McVitty refused him permission to cut wood for his own use off the leased land, he feels sore about this. He was convicted and sentenced to jail some years ago for buying grain and potatoes stolen from the Institute by some of the pupils. The Principal is blamed for this.

I tried in every way to show him that he was not dealing with the Institute but directly with the Department, that the School was there for the benefit of his own people, that the Department was prepared to treat him generously in the matter of rentals. He was headstrong and would give me no satisfaction only to say, "There is plenty of time before the last of April".

Some definite action will have to be taken right away. The school officials want to start driving manure onto the land in preparation for spring planting and they urged that the matter be settled with the least possible delay.

The lands concerned are not of such importance to the School, but the water supply cannot possibly be done without if the School is to be kept going.

Jerry Henry was the lessee of the lands covered by lease 586 when it was issued. Some years ago he traded lots with Louis McNeely the present lessee.

Norman Jameson owns the land covered by lease 586, and I understand, is willing to agree to a further term.

Sir; Lease No. 335, Mt. Elgin Institute.

With further reference to the above mentioned lease and previous correspondence dealing with the objections of Norman Gordon to the renewal of this lease I would advise that this Indian appeared at this office in a very hostile attitude and objected to his lands being leased at all and once again refused to accept the cheque for $3.50 in payment of rent for this year and in the same breath demanded relief which I have refused him until I get instructions from the Department.

This Indian now demands that only a five year renewal be given and proposes that his lands not be leased at all and he is willing to surrender what lands he needs any to the Department so that all the water pipe line will be on school property and cancel all leases, so that the control of his lands is placed in his own hands.

As the school is only using his lands because the pipe line runs on them at one point and more of land would cover the whole area of the water line there is much to back up the same claim and there will also be trouble if this lease be forced through as the same is of a useful nature and important and in the long run the pipe line would save many hundreds of dollars if this acre was taken from him and given a given back to balance which is not and has not been used by the school for a number of years.

If Mr. Inspector McGookin is to visit this Agency in the near future I would suggest that this whole matter of the lease be again reviewed with a settlement of this nature in view.

Yours obedient servant,

A. H. Moore, I.A.A., A.C.T.

The Reverend Principal of the Mount Alvin Institute on the Caradoc Reserve wishes to obtain a renewal of Leases Nos. 335 and 336, which cover two parcels of land in the Caradoc Reserve, containing respectively 27 acres and 57 acres. Both these leases have been in effect for a period of twenty-one years, and in both provision is made for renewal for a further twenty-one year period, on terms to be agreed upon.

For Lease No. 335 the Institute has been paying an annual rental of $15.00. For Lease No. 336 an annual rental of $30.00 has been paid. Inspector McGookin now recommends that these rentals be increased to $25.00 and $75.00 per annum respectively, and further, that the owner of the land involved in Lease No. 336 be permitted to cut on his leasehold from year to year such firewood as he may require for his own use, but not for sale. I would recommend your approval of a renewal of these leases, subject to the revised rental and the provision with respect to wood cutting.

I may say that these lands are urgently required by the Institute owing to the fact that the only available water supply for the Institute is located thereon, and in the development of which the Institute has expended very considerable sums.

Director.
Muncey, Ont.
January 23rd, 1933.

Sir;

Re: Leases Nos. 335 & 336,
Mount Elgin Institute.

With further reference to your letter RG-7F of August 20th, 1932, I would report that Mr. Inspector McCookin and myself made a visit to the home of Luis McGahey, with intentions of securing his consent to the renewal of Lease No. 336 and at the time of visit McGahey was reluctant to commit himself or state what terms he would agree to in case of renewal or whether he was agreeable to renewal at all. This Indian eventually stated that there was plenty of time to consider a renewal and there was no hurry about the same and also that he was of the opinion that the Mount Elgin Institute did not need his land as he was not interfering with their water supply and that he believed the line fence if placed in the proper position would show that the water catch basins were not on his land at all. From the fact that he holds 57 acres of land and judging from where the one catch basin is located I cannot understand his claim and would believe from viewing it with the naked eye that the catch basin is well on his property.

I am not aware what report Mr. McCookin will make in this case but would believe that it would be best that a survey be made of the lands both under lease No. 336, but also lands under lease No. 335 as these lines have long disappeared and it is not actually known where the line fences run at the present time as they have been under lease so long and dividing line fences have been removed. When these lines have been properly established definite steps can be taken with regard to renewal of these leases and McGahey would not be in a position to delay his decision longer on this pretext.

Your obedient servant,

A. D. Moore, Indian Agent.

Sir;-

Re; Mount Elgin School, Muncey.

I would advise you that the Rev. D. B. Strapp, Principal of Mount Elgin School has consulted me with reference to a number of land leases covering lands on the Oneida and Chippewa reserves, which either have to be renewed or allowed to lapse.

Lease No. 570 covering the lands of Solomon Schuyler should not be renewed, as this piece of land of 28 acres is separated from the rest and it is an added expense to keep up the fences for so small a tract which is the farthest distant from the school.

Lease No. 572 covering the lands of Mrs Lucy Fisher on the Chippewa Reserve should not be renewed for this 56 acres for during the past 5 years very little use has been made of this land and it was an expenditure that should not have been made due to the school not keeping as much stock and only needing the land part of the time.

Lease No. 573 covering what is known as Oneida lands, 154 acres and it is very necessary that this land be released and I would so recommend.

Lease No. 574 covering lands of W.K. Cornelius for 30 acres is also necessary for the school and I would recommend the land be released.

Lease No. 575 covering the lands of Mrs Levi Doxtator for 34 acres is also necessary for the school and I would recommend the land be released.

The last leases were for 5 year terms at a rental of $2.25 an acre and all the rents were paid in advance and in my opinion this rental was somewhat high in comparison with other lands leased on the reserves.
The Principal of the school considers these lands of more value to the school on account of their location adjoining the River Thames for a goodly supply of water and also that the fencing is kept low on the same account, and that the lands are across the river adjoining the school and can be kept under close supervision. I would suggest that the price of $2.00 an acre at the most be paid for these lands and that the leases be renewed at this rate, which receives the approval of the Reverend Principal.

As some of the leases run out at the end of this year and others on the 28th of Feb and 31st of March next, I would wish your authority to take the necessary steps for the renewal or that entirely new leases be drawn up for the five-year period.

Dear Sir:

Your letter of July 17th, 1940, re the Mount Elgin Residential School leases, is acknowledged, and the writer is quite prepared to accept personal responsibility for the delay in replying. When the matter was first referred to this division by Welfare and Training I had hoped to be able to satisfy myself on several points with reference to these leases by perusing several volumes of files relative to them. This took a lot of time and I regret to say that the files disclosed little or value.

The leases themselves, which expired in May, contain no provision for renewal. The Superintendent General has no power of which I am aware to lease the individual holdings of Indians on a reserve without their permission. You have furnished this office with no information on which a lease can be based. You may assure the Indians, however, that the Department wishes to rent their lands on the same terms as the former leases contained and that provision for payment will be made as soon as the formal leases can be prepared. In the meantime we will require the following information:

1. A list giving the names and band numbers of all owners whose lands are included in any of the four leases, Nos. 611, 613, 614, and 615.

2. A proper legal description of each separate parcel together with its acreage estimated as closely as possible.

3. A statement from your records showing the title in the claimant as clearly as possible.

A.D. Moore, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Muncey, Ontario.
4. A form of consent to the making of the leases signed by each individual owner, or if deceased by his proper legal representative. (This means the executor or administrator.

5. The amount payable to each owner out of the rent specified in the group lease.

I am sure that you will appreciate the fact that any consent formerly given expired with the leases on May 1st last so that new consents are essential.

Proper legal descriptions are important, and to assist you we are enclosing a sketch of the portion of the two reserves affected drawn to scale which is endorsed on the sketch. If the description in words cannot be clearly worked out you could put them in on the sketch giving me urgence. Any good linen tape would be all the equipment you would require. If you have no tape you can requisition one and we will send it to you.

It would appear from the file that some of the original owners are dead and that you are dealing with the heirs. In such cases the estates will have to be administered in order to ascertain to whom the money resulting from the leases should properly be paid.

It has been suggested to the writer that the rent reserved should be paid in annual installments rather than in a lump sum in advance. Such an arrangement would spread the income over the term and has something to recommend it. On the other hand we are not overlooking the fact that the Indians may have been assured that they would get their rent five years in advance, and if this is so it might not be practical to change it. We will be guided by your advice in the matter.

It is assumed that the land is in the use of the school for the present season. You can give the Indians the assurance that whatever happens this year's rent.......
rent will be taken care of. There should be no great difficulty in furnishing a satisfactory lease when the essential facts herein asked for are furnished.

The Welfare and Training Service have requisitioned the cheques for the Senecas under leases 335 and 336. You should receive them very shortly.

Yours truly,

Memorandum to: Director.

Re Leases covering lands used by the Mount Elgin Residential School at Munsey.

In the above connection we are renting approximately 220 acres of land from the Indians on the Munsey Reserve for the purposes of the Mount Elgin School. For approximately forty years we have rented this property by five year terms at a cost to the Department of approximately $200.00 per acre per five years. The actual rent is based on $200.00 per acre per annum which, according to values established elsewhere on this reserve and other reserves, means that we are buying the property every five years. This statement may be a little extreme but there is little doubt that the rent is excessive at present day values.

At the moment all leases have expired and the Department is in the position of over-holding tenants in relation to each of these Indians who is in effect our landlord. It is just possible that some arrangement might be made with the Indian owners for the sale of each of their holdings to meet the requirements of the school. If they were not willing under Section 11 of the Indian Act there would appear to be powers sufficiently wide to enable the Department to acquire the necessary land for school purposes at a valuation to be fixed by arbitration.

There are instances where the lands used by the school are subject to an interest by Indians other than members of the school and other instances where the leased land is involved in the estates of deceased Indians in connection with which the interests of the heirs should be sought out and determined.

All of these matters require time to completely investigate them, and it is therefore suggested that the Welfare and Training Division be authorized to issue cheques to the Indian owners according to the lists filed covering rentals for the year 1940-41 without the formality of a lease. If the situation remains as it is during the balance of the fiscal year that is left to us, an effort will be made to purchase the land we require from the Indian holders on reasonable terms. If this fails the Indians could be advised that under the authority of Section 11 of the Indian Act proceedings will be taken to acquire the land necessary for school purposes in payment to them of compensation fixed by arbitration.

If you concur in the above recommendations will you be so kind as to mark the proposal approved and return the file to Mr. Phelan of the Welfare and Training Division who on the strength of your approval will issue the rent cheques for the current year as above indicated.

Approved-

D.J. Allan,
Superintendent,
Reserves and Trusts.

Memorandum to: Mr. Hoey.

Re Mount Elgin Residential School.

I have no desire to be responsible for an intertribal war. You are using quite a substantial acreage of the Omaida Reserve in conjunction with the Mount Elgin School and have for many years been paying an annual rental of two dollars an acre for the land. Formerly this was rented for five years at a time and the whole proceeds handed to the Indian owners or locators in a lump sum. You will recall that last year we changed it to a one-year basis. Are you content to continue to rent this land on that basis? If you are the leases can be arranged.

I think we are all agreed that two dollars an acre is excessive. There is, however, some doubt as to whether or not we can expropriate for school purposes in the circumstances. It is also suggested that to try to do so would stir up a tremendous amount of ill feeling with the band. I am not satisfied as to the ownership of the various parcels but it will take years to straighten out these title messes with my present staff.

It is suggested that we might have a chat about the matter and decide on what course of action we are to pursue.

D.J. Allen.
Dear Sir:

Re Residential School Lands,

I would wish to again bring to your attention the leasing of Oneida Reserve lands for the use of Mount Elgin Residential School, that has been held in abeyance in accordance with your letter of August 7th, 1940.

William Cornelius of the Oneida Band and an influential Indian of that reserve has appeared at this office desiring that action be taken at an early date to lease these lands for a period of years. He claims to represent the Indians land owners and has a large acreage of his own and is asking that the leases be put through in time that the Indians may receive their rentals earlier than last year and that this money be available to aid them in planting their crops and gardens this coming Spring.

Cornelius also advises me that if the Department do not desire to rent this land, that it is the intention of the land owners to seek a tenant elsewhere. He also states that the owners are not desirous of disposing of their holdings by sale to the department and if it was the intention of the department to expropriate this land it would receive opposition from the land holders.

Kindly advise at an early date what action the department intends to take with regards the purchase or lease of this land, which is very necessary for the Mount Elgin School.

Yours truly,

I have your letter 7-0-9 of April 1st returning for correction the written authority granted by eleven members of the Oneida Band to lease their lands to Mount Elgin Residential School and will endeavour to re-sign these owners on a new authority on which the date has been changed from January 1st, 1941, to April 1st, 1941.

Last year I took the trouble to procure the signatures of these land owners at your request which the Department did not call for and you did, as overholding tenants, use the Indian land and pay the rental. Could not this rental be paid for this year in the same manner so that the Indian will have the funds in plenty of time to assist them in the Spring cultivation of their other lands?

It is hoped that the lease monies due these Indians will be sent forward as soon as available and that it will not be held up awaiting the return of their signed authority which will take some time to procure due to three of the Indians being absent from the Reserve.

Your obedient servant,

A. D. Moore, Indian Agent.

D. J. Allan, Esq.,
Superintendent of Reserves & Trusts,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

O.B. Strapp, Esq., Principal of the Mt. Elgin Institute, advises this office that the locators of the listed lots:

N/E portion of lot E Caradoc Reserve
Lots 21, 22, 23 and 24, Con; A.
S/E corner of lot 24 Caradoc
Part of lot P4

are requesting payment of rents.

The lease file notes that these lots were covered by leases, No. 611, 613, 614 and 615, but they all expired in April, 1940. Since that time there is no record of the lands being leased, although Mr. Strapp informs me the Institute has had the use of the lands and the locators have received their rents. I have verified by entries in the cash book, but just how the transaction has been handled I do not know. However, Mt Elgin Institute are anxious to continue and the locators all seem agreeable to the leasing, but would rather have them made out for a specified time. It would appear that these lands are leased by the educational services.

I would like some information as to how they have operated since 1940, and whether or not the locators will receive payment this coming first of May. It may be this office has been submitting an account for the whole amount since 1940. Please advise.

Dear Mr. Hoey;

With reference to the Oneida Land Leases, last year upon receipt of your letter informing me that it was your intention to continue these leases for the use of the school, I broke up about 80 acres of the high land and worked it as summer fallow. Mr. Agent Downs informed me that unless I obtain signatures to applications for renewal of these leases he will not forward an application to Ottawa for the renewals. I have obtained as many signatures as possible, and yesterday I returned the list to his office, giving his secretary the information that I did not know who, or where, the people were that held the balance of the land and that I felt that the best thing to do would be to leave the list in his office so that those who had not signed could do so if, and when, they called to inquire about the leases.

I am in receipt of a letter from Mr. Downs in which he says "I must now tell you very plainly, until the application form is complete, or the names without signatures erased, this office definitely refuses to accept it."

I am at a loss to understand the change in policy. Previously the whole matter has been handled by the Indian Agent as agent for the people and for the Indian Affairs Branch and the matter has been handled to the general satisfaction of all concerned. The Indian Agency is located in the village of Muncey and centrally located for all the parties concerned, it therefore seems to me to be the logical office to handle the matter.

I shall be pleased if you could give me permission to proceed with the work planned for this land, as it does not include the portion referred to in my letter of March 27th, owned by Mr. Jacob Rowling, who refuses to continue to lease his portion for the use of the school.

I have your letter of May 29th, and note that the Department was surprised to learn that I could not advise Mr. Arneil as to Antone's whereabouts.

To my mind there is nothing very surprising when you realize that we have a population of approximately two thousand people who are continually on the move. One of our most difficult problems is to locate persons or families for investigation. It is quite common for parents not to know where their children are and vice versa. Therefore I can hardly be expected to keep check on their movements.

I am obliged to inform you that I have been appointed to twenty-five dollars per acre May first of each year of lot 14 range 6 Township of Caradoc in the County of Middlesex in the Province of Ontario which is near to the Mount Elgin militia.

Yours (signature)
Ottawa,
May 18, 1944.

Mr. O.W. Down, Indian Agent, Muncey, Ont.

The Department is in receipt of a letter from Norman Seneca, requesting $25 rental for Lot 14, Range 6, Township of Caradoc, which he states is leased to the Mount Elgin Residential School. We have reviewed our files and the last payment we made for the lot mentioned above was in 1939 and presumably this particular parcel of land has not been used by the school since that time. However, I should appreciate it if you would discuss the matter with the Principal and advise this office.

For your information I may say that recently the Department forwarded Seneca a cheque for $25 rental for 27 acres of Lot 7, Range 7. Our records show that we have paid this amount yearly.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Muncey, Ontario,
May 18th, 1944.

Re Complaint, Norman Seneca
Mt. Elgin Lease

Your letter of May 15th is acknowledged. After contacting Mr. Seneca I have to report that he made a mistake in the lots quoted. The old survey describes the property as Lot 14, Range 6, whereas today it is described as Lot F, Range 7. As advised in your letter, he has received rental covering the property. We may therefore consider the matter closed.

Geo. W. Down,
INDIAN AGENT.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept' of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.
