re Agricultural Programme - Caradoc Reserve

The Agricultural programme for the current year at the Caradoc Agency has been discussed at length with Mr. Down and jointly a land inspection has been made. This programme has included 547 acres which reverts to the Agency on the termination of the Mt. Elgin Residential School on June 30th, and in addition approximately 200 acres throughout the Reserve being operated on an improvement basis to place the farmer occupant or future owner on a basis whereby he will be established in full time Agriculture. The operation of the above acreage is exclusive of other Agency agricultural activities such as partial cultivation of lands for individual farmers, the preparation of garden lands, the threshing of grain, clover and cash crops, the pressing of hay and straw and land drainage.

The 547 acres reverting from the Residential School can be broken up as follows:

- 210.5 acres, Government-owned, on which the buildings are located.
- 219.4 acres, pasture land, on the Oneida side—present lease terminates April 1, 1947. The rental of $2.00 per acre is chargeable to Schools. This land may be
pastured by the School herd until its disposal prior to June 30th.

117 acres on the Chippewa side adjoining the 210.5 acres. This area is also rented until April 1, 1947. It is largely arable and under crop, and is essential to the School farming unit. The entire School water supply is derived from a parcel of this land (the Seneca lot) which should be permanently acquired. The $2.00 rental for the current year is also chargeable to Schools.

The following plan is recommended for the operation of this land for the current season pending a decision being reached regarding the future operation of the School farm with its spacious outbuildings:

That 40 acres be summer-fallowed and sown to Fall Wheat.
That 25 acres be planted to late Potatoes.
That 40 acres be sown to Oats and Oats and Barley with 20 acres being seeded to Timothy and Clover.
That 120 acres be retained for Hay.
That 10 acres be partially summer-fallowed and sown to Buckwheat to be turned under to clean and improve the land.

This suggested programme is considered essential and the most economical having in mind the present condition of the land and the situation in the district at the School. The potatoes are realized and with the fall wheat and coarse grains are in keeping with the necessity of production on the Reserve. The School staff is at present seeding the 40 acres to Oats and Oats and Barley and they
have been requested to continue. A suggested arrangement has been reached to reimburse the School for the sowing and seeding of this 40 acres for the sum of $200.00 plus $40.00 for each ton of alfalfa seed used. In this arrangement we are supplying the seed for 20 acres of Oats otherwise the School is supplying all seed and grass seed. This nominal sum was suggested by myself as the minimum that could be offered and saves us at least an equal amount were they to cease operations. It represents around 25% of returns at present prices from an average crop. A good seed bed has been prepared and the work is being well done. From a financial point of view the operation of this land is largely to our advantage as the extensive hay land is average in seeding and with an average season should result in approximately 150 loads of mixed hay and alfalfa. We have the machinery for pressing hay and straw if necessary.

To effectively carry out this programme on the School farm and the ambitious programme on the Reserve some expenditures are essential. It will be recalled that our Welfare Power and Machinery has not been replaced during the past year and has been used and abused in the operation. A 10.20 International 9 years old and urgently in need of replacement. To keep this tractor in operation we are losing much time and needless expense. It is definitely in its last season. An International Farmall light tractor also about 9 years old and in similar condition to the 10.20. Our third tractor, an Oliver 70, is beyond repair and valued only as junk. We have never owned any haying machinery although it is urgently needed on the Reserve. I would recommend the immediate purchase of a light tractor, a six-foot cut mower, a side delivery rake, a wagon and rack and a hay loader. This recommendation covers minimum requirements for this year's operations. When it is
recalled that this 17,000 acre Reserve is entirely an agricultural one where 75% of the Indian families' revenue should be derived from this source it will be realized the absolute necessity of having adequate machinery in our endeavour to assist Indian land owners to become successfully established as full time farmers. The purchase of this machinery can be arranged by Mr. Down as soon as authority is received. In the case of the tractor needed at a scarce commodity at present it may prove necessary to purchase the School Tractor (a Farmall) at their auction sale. It appears serviceable but a new tractor is preferred and more economical in the long run.

I find a major problem confronting our administration of this Agency at present and one that should be corrected forthwith if confusion and loss of time and effort is to be avoided. It is the unfortunate absence of our Farming Instructor, Mr. Ryckman. I visited Mr. Ryckman and find him ill and preparing to go to Hospital for a rather serious operation. He will undoubtedly be absent for a long time and in view of his age it is my opinion that he has not been fit for any case at his age can I recommend his return to the heavy duties of Farming Instructor at this Agency. He has accumulated considerable Sick Leave and I presume will remain on pay for a good portion of the present growing season making the usual replacement at too late a date for current work. Mr. Down is in present position in long house and has succeeded in getting his spring work in splendid shape and well under way but it is impossible that he alone can carry the load.

I find an opportunity to temporarily replace Mr. Ryckman, on possibly a 90-day emergency payment on voucher basis, by a competent farming instructor already
in residence in one of the apartments at the Residential School. I refer to A.E. Bush the herdsman at the School. Mr. Bush is married, 53 years of age. He was born and raised on a dairy farm in Haldimand County near Hagersville. He has spent his life on the farm with the exception of some three years while employed in the Cockshutt factory at Brantford. He has owned his own farm and has had responsible jobs as herdsman in large breed Holstein herds in central Ontario. Mr. Bush has been at the School for some 16 months and has continually impressed me with his capability and practical common sense. In my opinion he is well qualified to take over the farming instructor's duties here and tide us over this emergency. He is willing to continue as long as the residential School contract remains, at a very early date, or as soon as the herd is sold possibly in May. If this can be arranged I would suggest a salary of $125.00 per month, plus house, fuel and light. He would simply remain on in the apartment. It is my strong recommendation that he be engaged on a temporary basis to permit this worthwhile program to proceed without disruption. In addition to the School farm and agricultural program he would be required to assist in our land drainage and roadwork activities.

I would appreciate consideration of these recommendations at as early a date as possible with advice to Mr. Down to enable him to lay his plans for the necessary implements and outside supervision.

W.S. Arnell
Inspector of Indian Agencies

These recommendations have resulted from discussion with Mr. Down who fully concurs. He is aware of all details of proposed operations.

Ottawa, April 20, 1946.

G. W. Dunn, Esq., Indian Agent, HUNTER, Ontario.

The Branch has received a memorandum from Mr. Inspector Arnell outlining a proposed agricultural program for the Cariboo Reserve.

For the present, at least, it will be necessary to farm the property formerly occupied by the Mount Elgin Residential School. Before next year we will have to decide whether we are prepared to run this as a demonstration farm, or reduce our holdings to that portion of the farm which belongs to us by allowing rented lands to revert to their Indian owners.

In order to carry on this summer it will be necessary to purchase certain farm implements, namely; tractor, side-delivery rake, six foot cut hay-mower, hay-clamp, grain bin and a rock. In connection with the tractor, we understand that it may be necessary to purchase the one belonging to the school, because of the difficulty of obtaining a new one. In view of Mr. Arnell's report on the mechanical condition of your present tractors we hesitate to add to the old machinery troubles by buying an old tractor. Purchase of a new tractor will take some time and we consider that you can manage with the present tractor until we can obtain a new one and turn in the evidence of the present trial. If you can we will order a new one. Please submit requisition, in duplicate, covering your machinery requirements. If you can attach quotations from local dealers and give us some idea of delivery date, this information will enable our Purchasing Agent to place his orders sooner.

Mr. Arnell has recommended that Mr. Bush, of the Residential School, be engaged in a temporary capacity to replace Mr. Eykman, the present Farm Instructor, during his illness—possibly for a three months period. This suggestion is tentatively approved. Payment for Mr. Bush's services should be made on monthly vouchers showing the following information:

... days' service at $...... to make up an amount of $125.00 per month.

Your suggested program for operating this land for the present season is approved. The licensees also concur in the proposed arrangement to rent out the school for seeding and seeding 40 acres by paying them $200.00 plus $40.00 to cover the cost of 2 tons of fertilizer, even with the estate.

It is suggested that a separate account be opened in your books to cover the Residential School Farm so that expenditure on it may be segregated. It will be in order for you to requisition funds you may require to cover labour, etc.

Director.

Reference is made to your letter of April 20th with regard to farming operations at the Mt. Elgin Residential School. We have had enquiries of the dealers in the Mt. Brydges area, and the Massey Harris dealer is the only one who will guarantee delivery in time for this season's harvest. I have attached, hereto, requisition covering the pieces mentioned in your letter which are all very necessary; and it is hoped that the order will be placed without delay.

There is very little difference in the set up and manufacture of the various types of recognized farm equipment, but there is an important factor which all good farmers consider. I refer to the readily available repair and parts service. The Massey Harris has such a shop in Mt. Brydges, 5 miles distant. It is therefore desired that the order be placed with them. There is also the consideration that they guarantee delivery in time for this season's operations which is a most important factor.

With regard to the tractor, please do not change the order to smaller size. It must also, on account of the exclusive loading from farms to farms, be on rubber. 25% of our repairs may be attributed to roadings on steel lug wheels. Massey Harris will guarantee delivery of this piece of equipment within three months. I must therefore manage with our present equipment until delivery is made.

I am now faced with the problem of a hay-rack which, if secured, will complete the requirements. This piece of equipment can only be secured through a local manufacturer and must be made to size. I am therefore requesting that I be given authority to have one made. The approximate cost is somewhere between $75.00 and $100.00.

If I am to receive this equipment in time to harvest this season's crop, please give the matter urgent consideration.

Muncy, Ontario,
March 12th, 1937.

Sir;

Mrs Stanley Dolson, a member of the Muncy Band of Indians at this Agency, has been under treatment from this office for some time. She suffers with an unresolved Pneumonia, and possible early Pulmonary Tuberculosis, although the latter disease has not been detected at the London Chest Clinic by the use of X Ray. This woman has a sister, Eva Doxtator, aged 17 years, who is a pupil at Mount Elgin Residential School, and she has repeatedly requested Indian Agent A.D. Moore and myself to obtain the latter's discharge from school so that the sister may care for her two children, and housework, while Mrs Dolson rests in bed as instructed by me.

Rev. O.B. Strapp, Principal of Mount Elgin School is loathe to discharge Eva Doxtator, assuming the view that with her domestic science course completed this summer, he will endeavour to place her at suitable employment in a private home. The girl herself is not anxious to leave school, but expressed a willingness to do so as a helpful duty to her sister.

Mr. Moore, Mr. Strapp and myself have discussed the situation, and the Principal of the school suggests that permission be sought for one month's leave of absence for Eva Doxtator to care for her sister, in lieu of discharge. Mr. Moore and myself concur in this proposal and the former has requested that I write for authority to have this girl granted leave of absence from Mount Elgin Residential School. I am, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

The Department has received a communication from the Medical Superintendent of the Cariboo Agency requesting that Eva Doxtator, a pupil of the Mount Elgin Indian Residential School, be granted one month's leave of absence in order that she can care for her sister, Mrs. Stanley Dolson. We are informed that the Medical Superintendent, Mr. Agent Moore and yourself have discussed the matter and that you were favourable of this girl being granted the leave requested.

The Department will approve of your permitting Ms. Doxtator one month's leave of absence. She should be returned to the school after that period. No per capita grant can be allowed for her during such absence, and in preparing your returns covering the period of her absence you should make a note after her name on the return stating the date she left the school, and, later, the date she is returned.

March 19th, 1937.

Dear Sir;

I am in receipt of your circular letter re preparation of the quarterly returns for residential schools.

Reference paragraph #4.

Very rarely do Indian Agents send even a copy of the application forms to the principal of the school. With the exception of Mrs. A.D. Moore the Agents do not even make a note with the pupils giving authentic information as to age, present attendance, school previously, and grade. When the pupils are brought to the school by their parents we can obtain the necessary information but many are brought by someone who can only guess at ages and grades. It would greatly facilitate the recording of necessary information if the Agents were instructed to forward the application forms to the Principal of the school who would then record the information and send the forms on to Ottawa. If you prefer to have the forms come directly to your office then the Agents could be instructed to send with every new pupil a note of introduction giving the necessary information. It something like this idea was in operation it would be easy enough for the Principal to be sure that the application of the child had been made through the proper channels. In our past we have had children brought to this school and only after they have been in school for some time have we discovered the Agent had not received an application for them; the parents of course say that they have authority from the Agent and we have no proof to the contrary.

With reference to the "Discharge" form.

As far as the records of this school are concerned it would appear that the former Principal discontinued the use of these forms in 1922. We would appreciate a new supply.

I remain,

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Principal.

In the p.m. of the 11th instant, Reverend O.B. Strepp, Principal of the Mt. Algic Residential School, telephoned the Detachment and complained that the two above named boys were Truant from the School.

An immediate patrol was made of the Reserve, by Police Corporal, Constable, and every effort made to locate them without success. A thorough search was made of all the barns and sheds on the school property as it was believed that they might stay in one of the buildings until dark and then make their way out of the school grounds. Members of the School Staff, assisted by older boys, searched the bush surrounding the School but failed to locate them.

Herman Henry is a member of the Munsey Reserve and likely places for him to visit have been searched. His parents and grandparents have been interviewed and state that he would not return home as they are anxious for his safety, remain in the school and could immediately reach him if he did come home.

The following is a description of the boys:

Herman Henry - Residence Munsey Reserve; age 15 years; height 5 feet 9 inches; weight about 130 pounds; wearing dark blue suit with pin stripe; dark blue windbreaker with zipper fasteners; dark grey felt hat; black overalls; white shirt with brown stripe.

Herman Thomas - Residence Kettle Point Reserve; height 5 feet 5 inches; age 17 years; weight about 150 pounds; black coat and trousers which do not match; dark grey felt hat; black overalls; white shirt.

It is requested that enquiries be made at the Kettle Point Reserve as it appears that they will have gone there.

Re: Ross Albert & Gordon Sahamation, Indian Juveniles.
Mt. Elgin Indian Residential School, Nunezy, Ont.

On the 2nd instant Reverend O.B. Strepp, Principal of the Mt. Elgin Indian Residential School, telephoned the Detachment and complained that the two above named boys were truant from school.

Although an immediate patrol was made of the Reserve and vicinity, per Police Chevrolet, code #296, no trace of the lads could be found.

In the p.m. of the 5th instant Reverend Strepp received a Long Distance telephone call from the Chief Constable, Niagara Falls detachment, stating that the two boys had endeavored to cross the border into U.S.A., but had been turned back and handed into his custody. Mr. Strepp requested that the boys be held and an escort would be sent to bring them back.

At 8 a.m. on the 6th instant, at the request of O.B. Strepp, a patrol was made to Niagara Falls by per private car which was supplied by the School. After reporting to the N.C.O. 1/s Niagara Falls detachment the boys were received into custody, Sahamation being held at the City Police Station while Albert was detained at the Children's Shelter.

The boys were returned to the School and handed over to the Principal, O.B. Strepp, at 9 p.m. of the same date.

Expenses shown on Form #33 for the period.

Dear Dr. Stewart:

The above noted child was examined at recent chest clinic held in Chatham on August 18th, 1937.

This child had no symptoms.

September 25th, 1937.

Dear Sir:

I reply to your letters as above noted would say that in the case of the Williams girls who are registered as Gladys and Velma George it is simply a matter of the mother thinking that they now are old enough to do some work and they could therefore perhaps be of use at home. While they were younger she was quite satisfied to have us look after them and now that they are old enough to make a contribution to the life of the school she would like to have them go. I beg to point out that it is imperative that we should have a percentage of pupils old enough to carry on the work of the school without any of them being at all burdened. These two girls are not yet fitted to go out to work and would only become a liability upon the reservation without anything to really occupy their time. Mrs. Williams mentioned the matter some time ago and when I raised the question it was admitted that there was someone around the house most of the time who could do the necessary chores etc. I would strongly recommend against their discharge.

Reference the Rogers children.

Mrs. Rogers visited the children at the school on Wednesday the 22nd. Inst., on that occasion she informed the Lady Superintendent that she had not known of the application made by Mr. Rogers for the children to be discharged from school. She stated that she was opposed to their discharge on the grounds that they would not receive the vocational training at the reserve day school and also they would not have the benefit of the discipline of the school which she felt they very much needed. I beg to point out that if they are discharged at this time the efforts already expended on their training will be largely wasted and it will have an unsettling effect upon the other pupils in the school. The elder girl, Hilda, has definitely expressed her resentment at the suggestion from her father that she be discharged and the other two are not yet old enough to know what they do want. Mr. Rogers' letter is merely a matter of following the line of least resistance and certainly is not in consideration of the welfare of the children nor the unsettling effect their removal would have upon other pupils. I beg to recommend that they be not discharged at this time.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

I would enclose application for admission and physical examination form for 10 pupils of Caradoc Agency who have been admitted to Mount Elgin Indian Residential School.

The following are the names of pupils, bands and dates of admission. Those marked X have T.B. free certificate attached to application form.

Your obedient servant,

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Chief of Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Following up our conversation during the teachers' convention with reference to transferring certain pupils from this school to Chapleau, I would like to say that I have made inquiries in the following cases.

No. 708 Irvin Johnson—Age 15, Sarnia Agency—this boy is sometimes known as Irvin Williams. He generally stays with grandparents or aunt when on the reservation during summer holidays. He was placed in school in 1932 as a neglected child.

No. 709 Clayton Fischer—Age 14, Sarnia Agency. The parents of this child are separated and the mother living part of the time with another Indian named Cotterill. The boy was placed in the school in 1932.

No. 739 Eddie Noah—Age 10, Walpole Island. This boy was being looked after by an Indian family—as he is a non-band member—and because of extreme neglect was placed in this school in 1934.

No. 672 Elsie Martin—Age 12, Cape Crocker. This girl's mother has been dead for a number of years. She was being looked after by other relatives and on petition of her reputed father, because of her neglected state she was placed in the school in 1930.

No. 671 Julia Sickler—Age 15, Caradoo Agency. Nothing is known about the parents of this girl. She has, however, been looked after partly by two brothers and a sister who usually work out in wood-cutting camps. She has no settled home on the reservation. She was admitted in 1930.

No. 6747 Josephine White—Age 13 Walpole Island. This girl's mother, Lena White, has been separated a number of years from her husband, and is employed in the United States. She has been making her home with a brother and sister who has been ill for some time. I am informed by Mr. Daley, the teacher at Walpole, that conditions in the home are very unsatisfactory.

I have submitted these names for your consideration as I believe them to be the ring leaders among the truants.

I would appreciate it very much if you could see your way clear to issue definite instructions to your acting Agent at Sarnia with reference to the immediate return of truants from this school and also
inform him of the section in the Indian Act providing for attendance at residential schools after age 16. Sarnia is still the 'Mecca' for runaways. Two from the Six Nations agency and one from Caradoc left us yesterday after informing some of the other boys that they were going to Sarnia, and the Agent there would get them out of school. Much of this I believe is hearsay amongst the Indian children, but from information received from the police, I am afraid there is some basis in fact for their assertions.

I am, dear sir

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Ottawa, October 22, 1937.

Dear Canon Valois—

I was at the Mount Elgin Indian Residential School at Muncey, Ontario, last week and I found that three boys and three girls have been truanting. Their actions are affecting the other pupils and it is considered advisable to place them in another school.

Instructions are therefore being issued to send them to Chapleau.

As mentioned above, there are no other complaints against these children other than truancy and as you require additional pupils, I felt that you would be pleased to receive them.

The following particulars regarding these children have been received from Rev. O.B. Strapp, of the Mount Elgin Residential School:

No. 705 Irvin Johnson - Age 15, Sarnia Agency. This boy is sometimes known as Irvin Williams. He generally stays with grandparents or aunt when on the reservation during summer holidays. He was placed in school in 1932 as a neglected child.

No. 709 Clayton Fischer - Age 15, Sarnia Agency. The parents of this child are separated and the mother is living part of the time with another Indian named Cotterill. The boy was placed in the school in 1932.

No. 739 Eddie Noah - Age 10, Walpole Island. This boy was being looked after by an Indian family—as he is a non-band member—and because of extreme neglect was placed in this school in 1934.

No. 0711 Elsie Martin - Age 12, Cape Crocker. This girl's mother has been dead for a number of years. She was being looked after by other relatives and on petition of her reputed father, because of her neglected condition was placed in the school in 1930.

No. 0715 Julia Dickens - Age 15, Caradoc Agency. Nothing is known about the parents of this girl. She has, however,
been looked after partly by two brothers and a sister who usually work out in wood-cutting camps. She has no settled home on the reservation. She was admitted in 1930.

No. 0747. Josephine White — Age 13 Walpole Island. This girl's mother, Lena White, has been separated a number of years from her husband, and is employed in the United States. She has been making her home with a married sister who has been ill for some time. I am informed by Mr. Daley, the teacher at Walpole, that conditions in the home are very unsatisfactory.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Rev. Canon A.J. Vail,
Principal, Indian Residential School,
Chapleau, Ont.
Ottawa, October 22, 1937.

Reverend Sir:

With reference to your letter of October 20th, the Department approves the transfer of the following pupils from the Mount Elgin Indian Residential School to the Chapleau Indian Residential School:

Irvin Johnson, No. 708 - Elsie Martin, No. 0711
Clayton Fisher, No. 709 - Julia Siddles, No. 0715
Eddie Noah, No. 722 - Josephine White, No. 0747.

You can, no doubt, make enquiries regarding train connections. The children should be taken to Toronto ... from that point there a daily train via Canadian Pacific Railway to Chapleau.

The cost of transferring these children should be kept as low as possible, but payment of the expenses incurred will be met on receipt from you of properly certified account, in triplicate, to which receipts should be attached.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Dr. McLeod:

Mrs. Julia General, Age 13 yrs.

The above noted patient was examined at chest clinic held in Victoria hospital on September 23rd, 1937.

No history of exposure to tuberculosis. Tonsils and adenoids had been removed at a previous date.

On examination her temperature was 99.2; pulse 92; weight 79-1/4 pounds. Examination of the chest showed good chest expansion. Nothing abnormal found.

Intracutaneous tuberculin test reported negative. X-ray report as follows: "Examination of the chest shows definite thickening of the hilum areas on both sides with calcified nodes and old healed lesions which are small and sharply circumscribed in the parenchymatous tissue. These are more marked on the right side and there is also interlobar pleural thickening on the right side. Apparently there is some pleural thickening of the left side. Diagnosis: Chronic-nodular tuberculosis."

Conclusions: Although this girl had a negative tuberculin test we feel that she has had a childhood tuberculous infection, however, this is well healed at the present time. We also noticed a number of scars and infected areas on this girl's hands suggesting previous scabies infection.

We trust this report is satisfactory and thank you for referring this patient to us.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Dear Mr. Strapp:

Enclosed is a statement showing the reports received from the R.C.M.P. in connection with truants from the Mount Elgin Indian Residential School. In several cases since the beginning of October, reports have also indicated that some of those who ran away in September also truanted again on one or two occasions.

As the truancy is apparently continuing, the matter is giving the Department some concern.

December 6th, 1937.

Dear Mr. Phelan;

In reply to your letter of the above date and file number would say that the six pupils were transferred to the Chapleau school on December 1st. The only outstanding truant at this date is Howie Greenbird and he is apparently staying with relatives in the U.S.A. He will probably return to the reservation at some later date and can then be apprehended and returned to school.

Several things seem to have contributed to the general unrest amongst them being the fact that during the holidays so many of the pupils were able to get work and earn money, pupils working for a short while earning as high as $2.50 per day and living with relatives who did not charge them for board. Upon investigating the conditions of # 0794 Gladys Laforme I find that she has been in the habit of leaving her home whenever she wandered about the country for a while and then when she felt like it, returning home and carrying on as if nothing at all had happened and she apparently felt the urge to wander again. I have only received a definite complaint from one pupil, Eddie Noah, and it was to the effect that he had to carry in wood for the fires in the Laundry. As we operate our laundry only one day per week I felt that he certainly was not overtaxed as he had two helpers and was only responsible for the job from 8 A.M. to Noon. During that time the three boys would have to bring in about 2½ to 3 single cords as required.

From time to time we do have complaints that we do not serve meat often enough. Unfortunately we are compelled to purchase all our meat from the butcher as we have no facilities for cold storage. If we had a meat refrigerator we could kill our own cattle and provide meat on the menu more frequently.

May I express my sincere appreciation of the action of your department in transferring the six pupils to another school; it has had a marked effect upon a number of the other pupils who have truanted and I believe has settled the matter at least for this year.

I beg to enclose the vouchers for the expenses incurred in connection with the transfer of the six pupils.

I remain,
Yours truly

Dear Sir:

Yours of the 14th inst. received advising me of my daughter, Phyllis's mis-conduct, this is really shocking to me.

I believed that she was quite contented to stay there at school till she finished her term, and I am sorry I am giving you some trouble and I cannot think of anyone who she would run away. The only thing I can think of is that when I heard early this fall, that a group of girls were punished for something they had done and Phyllis was one of them, and my opinion is this, that she resented being punished for something she was not entirely to blame for, and it is likely that she will never forget the offense given her by some unsuspected offender and I doubt whether I could persuade her to tell me where the trouble lies. I am speaking from my own experience when I was there, and once I was punished for some things that I didn't do. I will never forget those who gave me the punishment, in spite of my protests, and this is the general experience of most of the ex-pupils.

So, I would suggest that you try to win Phyllis by kindness and perhaps she will tell you where the trouble is. You must consider that she is at the age now that she will appreciate a treatment accorded to an older person, and will respond to any confidence given her.

I am enclosing one dollar for her and I am leaving it entirely in our care. Tell her that she is causing me a great deal of anxiety, and ask her if she wants me to be happy, to promise that she will be a good girl. Anxiously awaiting a favourable report.

Dear Mr. Phelan;

I have your letter of the above date and file and in reply would say that I have given a great deal of attention to this matter. I have to confess that I am somewhat baffled by the attitude of Phyllis Plain who appears to be the leader in the group. She admits that she 'just took the notion' and 'has been in school too long'. The other girls say that they 'just went with her'. I think that Lillian Peters was feeling rather blue as since she came to school three years ago her people have not bothered very much about her and have neither arranged for her to go home for her holidays nor visited her at the school. She is rather a moody type of girl and neglect on the part of her relatives has probably had an influence upon her. George is like a little wild animal and has given us considerable trouble. Anna Kim has been an exceptionally well behaved girl and has made good progress in the vocational classes but is at a standstill in her public school work.

Some time ago I wrote to Chief Nicholas Plain of Sarnia suggesting that he pay a visit to the school but he replied that he would leave the matter to me. I enclosed a dollar bill for his daughter Phyllis. I felt that if I could get him to make a visit and spend some time amongst the pupils he might be able to make some suggestions as to the real cause of the unrest.

These girls were absent from the school for about four hours from the time that they left until their return by the R.C.M.P. Howie Greenbird was returned after being absent since September 26th, and informs us that he has been at home at Walpole Island during that time helping his father.

Howie and the four girls seem to have settled down and I do not anticipate any further trouble from them.

I beg to make the following recommendations:

Re. Phyllis Plain; This girl very evidently is at the age when she needs sympathetic supervision and kindly but firm discipline. I believe that if we can keep her along until the end of June it would then be advisable to arrange for her discharge. But for the fact that I am afraid of a re-action similar to that following the discharge of the George girls of Sarnia last October I would be glad to be relieved of any further responsibility for her.

I quite agree that she is at the age when she should have careful supervision and I doubt very much whether, if she went home, her father or her step-mother could do very much to control her. Dear Sir:-

Attention Mr. Philip Phelan.

With further reference to your letter 7-0-10 of the 21st instant with enclosures from Mrs. Sam Simon requesting discharge of her daughter Rachael, who is a pupil of Mount Elgin Residential School, I would report that I have discussed this case with the Principal and it is agreed that it would not be to her interest to allow her to return home at the present time.

This girl who is listed on the school records as 17 years of age has been receiving treatment from Doctor McLeod, Medical Superintendent, for some time for a condition of arthritis. Both her parents have syphilis and the daughter is a congenital case. Doctor McLeod disagrees with the statement that he has seen her 3 times since the onset of her illness and estimates that a dozen attendances would be more in order which statement is borne out by the Principal.

The family reside in a small shack on the Chippewa Reserve which has recently been enlarged with lumber provided by the Department. Sole subsistence this winter has been by relief supplied by the Department. An older sister, Kathleen, discharged from Mount Elgin School last spring has done no gainful work since and according to a report received by Principal Strapp is now believed to be pregnant.
In the opinion of this office, including Doctor McLeod and Principal of the school, Rachael Simon can be much better cared for at the school under a trained nurse and supervisor. She has been placed in bed near a radiator and is being given special food to improve her condition.

There is a slight suspicion that this girl may be pregnant following a visit to her home during Christmas vacation from which she returned with an ample supply of cigarettes, seized by the school authorities.

Doctor McLeod is investigating the pregnancy angle and it may be necessary to admit her to hospital for a few days to confirm or dispel this condition.

Mr. Strapp informs us that since his refusal to discharge this girl from school she has become unruly, disobeying orders and refusing at times to take food. Such action usually follows a visit from her parents whom he blames for the girl's behaviour. Morals in the Simon home are open to question and it is no fit place to return a girl whose health is under par.

There is no record here as to whether the application for Residential School was signed and Principal Strapp believes that if there were no signature, such was due to the fact that Indian Agent Thomas McCookin peremptorily removed this child from intolerable surroundings in 1928. Mr. McCookin is quite familiar with the home conditions and could amplify this report if such is desired.

If this girl is as old as her mother claims, she could be discharged from Mount Elgin School at the end of the term next June, in the meantime, she will receive adequate medical attention as heretofore and Mr. Strapp is in favour of this recommendation.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter 7-0-10 of March 11th enclosing correspondence regarding Rachael Simms, a pupil of Mount Elgin Residential School, I would report that I have shown the Chief's letter to the Principal of the School and the Medical Superintendent. Both Mr. Strapp and Dr. McLeod have already attempted to assure those interested that the School authorities are acting in the girl's best interests.

Doctor McLeod reports that this girl is suffering from a condition of arthritis and that it would be very inadvisable to discharge her to the deplorable home conditions under which her family exists. With the services of a graduate nurse at Mount Elgin School and constant medical attention she has shown some improvement, although her mental attitude, abetted by her parents, is not one of cooperation in an effort to get well.

Last week when a Dental Clinic was conducted at the School, this pupil was examined by Doctor Auckland, who recommended three tooth extractions and several fillings. This girl, who is practically an adult, refused to permit the Dentist to work on her teeth and carried on to such an extent that Doctor McLeod advised that no force be used in view of the attitude already assumed by her parents. The dental work indicated would assist in combating her arthritis materially.
When shown the letter of Chief Deleary, Principal Strapp affirmed that this girl is receiving every attention both by the Medical Superintendent and the Institute Staff. Although special menu was prepared for her by the dietitian, the girl went on a hunger strike, which was successfully broken by the Principal, who is of the opinion that advice from home has a bearing on her stubborn attitude.

Doctor McLeod states that if this girl were removed to hospital, it would be a long, drawn out and expensive care and that her welfare can be equally protected at the School.

With reference to Chief Deleary's statement that the parents are not on relief, our records show that the father of this girl received, since November, 1937, seven rations. The pension received by him was inaugurated in December and amounts to, approximately, $5.50 per month.

In view of the fact that this pupil is receiving special care at the hands of Doctor McLeod and the Mount Elgin School staff, I would recommend that no action be taken in this case.

Chief Deleary's letter is returned.

Prol.

On the afternoon of the 16th instant in an interview with the Rev. Mr. O.B. STRAPP, Principal, of Mount Elgin Indian Residential School at Muncy, I learned that the above named boy of about fifteen years of age and a student at the school, had contracted gonorrhea. The boy was re-examined thoroughly by both Mr. STRAPP and the medical Superintendent Dr. T.R. McLeod but stoutly maintained that he had not had contact with a woman or girl. He stated however that he had had sexual relations with a son in a barn at the residential school, about a month previous to his illness. Dr. McLeod states that the boy must have at some time or other had connections with a female human being to have contracted the disease.

Sub-Division

On the afternoon of the 18th instant I proceeded to the Mt. Elgin residential School and in company with the principal interviewed the boy Peter MYERS. The lad denied absolutely having anything to do whatsoever with a woman, but readily admitted his intercourse with the son in the barn so far as to take us to the barn and point out the boy in question from amongst several others. He stated that he had had these connections on two different occasions. Mr. STRAPP stated that he wished to take the necessary action in having this matter attended to.

Detachment

On the afternoon of the same date whilst in London, I interviewed Major A.G.M. BRADSHAW, Chief Probation Officer at the Juvenile Court. I was advised by him to lay a charge against this case under Section 152 of the Criminal Code of Canada before Major BRADSHAW. I was instructed to bring the boy before Juvenile Judge D.F. July 6, 1938.

Dear Sir:

On your recommendation, Peter Myers was placed in the Mount Elgin Residential School in September, 1929, and has remained there since that time. In the latter part of May, Peter was brought before the Judge of the Juvenile Court on a charge of a grossly indecent nature and, owing to medical evidence given at the hearing, the Judge remanded Peter to Victoria Hospital for treatment.

As soon as he was released from hospital he was again brought before the Judge, who decided that it would be in the best interests of all parties concerned to commit Peter to the Ontario Training School for Boys. This institution is located at Bowmanville, Ontario, and is operated by the Ontario Government. This Department will be responsible for his maintenance there.

I have recently been informed that a relative, D. K. Oshgees, of Wallaceburg, has been making enquiries about Myers, and I would appreciate your seeing Oshgees as soon as possible and explaining to him the contents of this letter. You should also inform him that the Department considers the action taken is in Peter's own interests. The Ontario Training School for Boys is a well conducted institution, where Peter can learn a trade.

Yours truly,

T. R. C. MacInnes,

Dear Sir:

Mr. Nelson Peters, an Indian living on the Muncey Reserve, whose address is Melbourne, Ontario, has consulted us regarding his son Ronald Peters. It appears that this boy was attending the Industrial School at Muncey for the past two years and went on two-thirds part of July of this year he became ill. The father first became aware of the illness on the 12th of July and after having him examined by a doctor he was immediately placed in Victoria Hospital, London, and remained there until the 23rd of August of this year. The boy was suffering from an infection of the kidney and was in very serious condition and as yet has not fully recovered.

The boy has been examined by the resident physician on the Reserve and also by a physician in private practice. When the boy left the hospital the father was advised that he would have to be very careful for several months as the condition might recur. The physician on the Reserve wants the father to send the boy back to the Industrial School but the father feels that in view of the fact that half of the day is taken up with work and half with school that the Industrial School would be too much for him in his present condition and has refused to send him back until his physical condition has improved.

There seems to be a controversy between the father and the physician on the Reserve as to the advisability of sending the boy back and the father wanted us to see the story placed before you, as he states positively that he will not consent to the boy going back at the present time. We do not know just who has authority in a matter of this kind and the father has, therefore requested that we write to you giving you the circumstances and it may be that you can perhaps do something in regard to this.

Yours truly,

SHILLINGTON & HOFFMAN

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 12th instant regarding Ronald, son of Nelson Peters, member of the Muncey of the Thames Band of this Agency and his proposed return to Mount Elgin Residential School. I would advise that Dr. McLeod inform me that this case was discussed with Mr. Moore some time ago and it was decided not to return him to the Residential School at the present time.

This boy suffered a serious attack of acute nephritis or kidney disease in July and was in hospital for several weeks during which time his recovery was not expected. He is still under the attention of the Medical Supt. but has progressed to such an extent that he has been able to walk about daily and there is no trace of kidney infection.

Dr. McLeod proposed to Mrs. Peters that it would be to the advantage of her son to return to Mount Elgin Residential School where he would be given plenty of rest with no work at all and would have a warm bed and shelter, much more favourable than his home conditions. The proper diet available at the School was also drawn to her attention and the Principal of the School expressed his willingness to cooperate.

Mrs. Peters quite definitely refused this suggestion declaring that she was determined to keep her boy at home.

In view of the fact that for some time this boy will remain semi-invalid and that there is a possibility of the kidney condition returning with tragic results, Mr. Moore and Dr. McLeod concluded that it would be advisable to allow this boy to remain at home and not expose the Department to possible unfair criticism.

At no time was it stated to the Peters family that their son would be forced to return to school and the consultation with Mr. Huffman appears to have been rather premature.
It is interpreted from your letter that a medical certificate would be necessary only if this boy returned to the school against the desire of his parents. If such a certificate is necessary so absent himself from residential School, Dr. McLeod is prepared to furnish same.

The family is quite anxious that he continue his education and arrangements have been made with the Day School teacher of the Beer Creek School to provide him with lessons to be done at home during his convalescence.

Dr. McLeod reports that he saw Ronald Peters at his home on Sept. 13th and at that time assured Mrs. Peters that it would not be necessary for her son to return to Mount Elgin Residential School.

Your obedient servant,

M. W. McCracken

Dear Mr. Spence:

We have your letter of September 15th regarding the above noted and are enclosing the Certificate of Health, completed, as requested.

We might say that this boy entered Queen Alexandra Sanatorium on June 6th, 1932, and a diagnosis of minimal pulmonary tuberculosis made with evidence of previous right pleurisy. He has been a patient with us since that time and during his residence on no occasion have we found evidence of tubercle bacilli in his sputum.

Radiographic study from time to time showed improvement of the chest disease, at the present time this being considered as well healed.

In September 1932 the patient showed suggestive evidence of synovial disease of left hip joint. Immobilization in plaster was carried out until June 1934 when radiographic study showed suspicious tuberculous disease of the right hip joint. Plaster spica was continued until January 1937 when the patient was allowed up and around in a left calliper splint. Since that time the patient has been up and around the ward with considerable exercise outdoors daily, enjoying perfect health. At the present time there is practically no signs on physical examination of disease in either hip joint, this being confirmed radiographically.

In our opinion this boy, who is remarkably bright and co-operative, should do well at school, and we heartily recommend his application for approval.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

I feel that with the amount of money and care he has received during his stay in the sanatorium he should not be neglected in any way now and I am at a loss to find a suitable home for him on the Reserve, his mother having died a number of years ago, and his father lives alone on the Reserve, whom I could not recommend as one who would give the boy proper attention."

Dear Sir:

Maitland French, No. 358 of the Chippewa Band who has ten children, is protesting the return of his daughters, Iris aged sixteen and Beulah aged fifteen years, to Mount Elgin Residential School after the summer vacation period claiming that Iris is old enough to work and had a position and that Beulah was not receiving the proper medical attention at the School for an infected toe. Iris was allowed out in December, 1937, to assist at the serious illness of her mother and from that time has not returned to the Residential School as promised by her parents.

I did take the case of Iris up with the Reverend Principal of the School as I was of the opinion that Iris, having a good position in the home of Florence Trott, ex-reeve of Caradoc Township, should be discharged and allowed to remain there but Mr. Strapp was very determined to have the girl return to the School which she did on October 6th. This girl is sixteen years old and is not nearly ready for her Entrance examination and has not shown any great progress in her book studies and if only returned to the School for domestic training purposes she would have gotten that at Mr. Trott's home and besides would have been earning money to help her family also making room for a needy child at the Residential School.

I would ask your opinion and instructions as to this girl being discharged to whom Mr. Strapp will not agree although he admits with her return, he will have exceeded the 150 pupil allowance at his School.
With regard to Beulah, I would advise you that this girl has an ingrown toe nail and was let out at summer vacation with it not being cured and during her term at the Residential School this toe was never reported to Doctor McLeod although it was treated by the school nurse.

At the time for this girl's return to the School it was found to be infected and had been opened by an outside Doctor and French protested his girl returning to the School claiming she was being neglected. Doctor McLeod now knows of this ailment of Beulah's and advises me he will have it attended to and if necessary have a surgical operation after the infection has subsided and in Dr. McLeod's opinion this ailment at no time assumed serious proportions. This girl also returned to the school on October 8th and her continuance there as a pupil is recommended.

Maitland French claims he can support his large family but I would advise you that this man has always received some relief assistance in the way of food, fuel, clothing and building materials every winter in the past and I am doubtful if he can again ask for assistance this winter.

January 18, 1939.

Reverend Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 13th instant the discharge of Morris Antone, No. 704, from the Mount Elgin residential school is approved.

I cannot find any record on our file of a promise being made that supernumerary grant would be allowed for the Doxtator and Chrisjohn children. I understand these children did not enter the school until some time in July and it is not usual for us to authorize supernumerary grant at that period of the year.

During the past two months we have received several reports from the R.C.M.P. regarding truancy. Possibly it is the same children that are truanting but in any case I have no doubt that you have fully investigated conditions leading up to the truancy of these pupils and that you have taken whatever steps are necessary to prevent it in the future.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I regret very much to have to report that Vera Martel of the Rama Agency has proven very unsatisfactory as a pupil in this school. When she first came to us she said that she only intended to remain here for a month or two and only wanted to take cooking classes. I had a talk with her and suggested that it would be very much better for her to at least stay until the end of the school year and learn all that she could in the practical departments and in the meantime take the matter up with her Agent. She wrote to Mr. Featherstone and he replied in what I thought a very nice letter and suggested that she was very much better off in school where she would have an opportunity to learn much that she could not learn at home. Since then despite every effort on our part to make her comfortable and change her viewpoint she has done nothing but complain and at present is proving a very disturbing influence in the school. I very much regret that I have to request that arrangements be made to return her to Rama at the earliest date as may be possible.

The Anderson girls and Elsie St. Germain seem to be happy and are proving apt pupils.

I remain,

Yours truly,

ALDERSHOT, Ontario,
Feb. 15 - 1939.

To Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Canada.

Sir:

I beg to submit this letter for your immediate and favorable consideration on behalf of Mrs. and Mr. John Noah in relation to a boy (Norman Stonefish, Jr.), Member of the Moravian Town Band of Indians, age 6 years. Who was deserted by his mother, Mrs. Norman Stonefish, Sr., and left here at the house of Mrs. and Mr. John Noah on the 22nd of April, 1938, and has been kept by Mr. Noah ever since, with no help from any source. Mr. Norman Stonefish, Sr., father of this boy, has been working in this neighborhood all last summer of 1938, but refuses to contribute anything towards the support of this boy. As Mr. and Mrs. John Noah are non-members of the Band, and they feel they are unjustly treated when they are doing their best for the boy - they buy clothing and fit him out, so he could go to school every day, and all they get during the whole time is $4.40 in clothing from S. Spence, Indian Agent, with instructions to send him a receipt for any clothing bought for the boy, which they have done. But they did not get anything for it yet, as you will see by the letter written by Mr. Spence, Indian Agent. Also they requested Noah to bring the boy to the Reserve, but they did not offer or provide any funds for that purpose. As Mr. John Noah cannot go to any further expense as he has his own family to look after.

Mr. Norman Stonefish, Sr., was here on the night of Feb. 4, 1939 in an intoxicated condition, and making a disturbance with Mr. Noah's family. County Police had to be called to take him away from there, and he came over to my home that night, and I know he was very much intoxicated and he admitted to me he was drinking, and he was in no condition to look after a child that time of the night. I understand Police instructed him to come after the boy the next day when he was sober, but he left and never came back. Mr. Stonefish, I understand, has rented his home to someone on the Reserve, and he would have no place to take the boy, but to be left here and there, and to be knocked about. So I would humbly suggest that action should be taken at once to place this boy in a Boarding school - Mt. Elgin School, Muncey, and further, Mr. and Mrs. Noah wish to ask the Department to remunerate them for the keep of the boy at the very small rate of Two ($2.00) dollars per week, which would include all they have bought in clothing for the boy - ten months to 22nd of Feb. 1939. This could be paid for by the Department, and interest money of both Mr. & Mrs. Stonefish, retained until this is paid back in full, and after that the money of the parents should be kept for the children for their future use by the Department of Indian Affairs.
The above is humbly submitted for your kindly and favorably consideration.

Ever yours,

(sgd) EVERSON SNAKE,
ALDERSHOT, Ont.

Dear Friends:

No doubt you have been waiting for an answer all this time. The Agent was to have sent an order ($3.60) lately, for the boy. I hope you have rec'd it by this time.

It was the ruling of the Inspector, McGugan, that we send the boy to some residential school. We are acting on the advice of the Inspector, knowing that it is to the welfare of the boy.

In the Spring of 1924 Mr. Stewart visited me at the Reserve. That was a good day for me because I had just returned from a trip back home. We discussed the possibility of coming back again, but I couldn't make any plans.

The following year, in December, I visited the Reserve again. This time, however, I did not have the opportunity to see Mr. Stewart. Instead, I went to visit my family in Ontario. It was a long trip, and I didn't have enough money to pay for it. Despite this, I decided to go anyway.

I arrived at the Reserve on December 25th. I met Mr. Stewart there, and we talked about our plans for the future. He seemed very enthusiastic about the idea of coming back again next year.

Stuart Stone

The above named Indian boy appeared before the Judge of the Juvenile Court at London Ont. on this date. Due to the lack of intelligence of the boy he was not asked to plead. The Court ordered him to see the Principal of the school and the parents of the child. This individual, an Indian woman of rather low culture had very little to say outside of admitting that she had harboured the boy when he truanted from the school. The Judge spoke to her severely about this and also reprimanded the boy who promised faithfully that he would attend school without giving any trouble in future. He promised the Judge and the parents that he was willing to give young TOMEGO another chance to behave. The Judge then instructed the boy to return to school with the Principal. This was done and it is thought that the appearance in Court of this student will act as an example to the other students in the school as well as having a desirable effect on young TOMEGO.

Muncey, March 17th, 1939.

Dear Sir:

I would acknowledge receipt of your letter 7-0-10 of March 9th advising that A. B. Jiskind, Barrister, London, Ontario, had written to the Department concerning the discharge of Clayton and Martin McGahey from Mount Elgin Residential School.

To supplement the report made by this office on August 8th, last, and your report of August 16th, I would advise that Donald School informed us that Andrew McGahey, one of these boys, is a chronic case of heart trouble and is unable to do any work. He is in receipt of $15.00 a month soldier pension which has been granted since the children have been placed in the school and also receives $6.00 per week salary as caretaker of the old Settlement Indian Day School which janitor work is done by his wife. Besides the two boys in Mount Elgin School, there are three small children under school age.

On consulting the Rev. Principal of the school I was advised that both boys are good pupils and that the elder, Clayton, is in Grade 6 having a 75% standing in his year's work so far. Also that the younger boy, Martin, is in Grade 6 with an 80% standing which is lower due to his being a run-away truant part of the term.

Mrs. McGahey is a woman much younger than her husband who has had a number of affairs with other men and if this couple would remain at home she could well carry on the duties as janitor of the school and provide the needs of the house with the exception of cutting firewood.

It is the recommendation of this office that, if Clayton McGahey, the elder boy, passes his Entrance examinations in June when he will be 16 years of age, he receive his discharge and, failing that, to be kept in the school another year. The younger boy, Martin, should remain here not more than one year.

Mrs. McGahey has been very abusive with the principal of the school in threatening the removal of the children, hence her visit to Mr. Jiskind. I would ask that the Department's decision be made known to Mr. Jiskind and thereby conveyed to her as I believe this would carry weight and possibly stop her interference at Mount Elgin School.

Yours obedient servant,

A. D. Moore, Indian Agent.

Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I desire to refer to your letter of the 6th ultimo and my reply of the 9th ultimo with reference to Martin and Clayton McGehey, pupils of the Mount Elgin Indian residential school.

The father of these boys has a chronic case of heart trouble and is unable to do any work. Besides the two boys in the Mount Elgin school there are three small children under school age at home. It is reported that Mrs. McGehey does not stay at home and attend to her household duties as she should.

Both the boys in the Mount Elgin school are good pupils, the elder, who is in grade 8, having a 70% standing on the current year's work. The younger boy is in grade 6 and only has a 30% standing. This is due in part to the fact that he truanted for part of the term.

Mrs. McGehey has been very abusive with the Principal of the Mount Elgin residential school in threatening the removal of her children.

In view of the progress being made by the boys and the further fact that home conditions cannot be considered totally satisfactory this Department considers that it is in the best interests of these two boys to remain in the Mount Elgin Indian residential school and we are, therefore, not prepared to approve their discharge at the present time.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir: Attention Mr. Philip Phelan,

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of April 15th enclosing a communication received at the Department from James Cornelius of the Oneida of the Thames Rand who desires that his daughter Cassie be discharged from Mount Elgin Residential School so that she may keep house for him.

Cassie Cornelius was admitted to this school in September 1930 at which time her age was given as eight years and she must be seventeen years of age at this time. This girl has just recently been promoted to the 8th grade in her classes but will not try her entrance this Summer, which proves that she is not an adept pupil.

Mrs. James Cornelius is in the Ontario Hospital, London, leaving at home her husband James and a son about fifteen years of age. Cornelius did for a time have a widow keeping house for him, but she has now left and he claims he is unable to procure another.

Mr. Strapp is not anxious to keep this girl after the present Summer holidays and in keeping her would only be endeavoring to keep her out of trouble on the reserve. As this father has a need of this girl at his home on the reserve I would recommend that she be discharged at the end of the present school term. The letter of James Cornelius is returned herewith.

Dear Sirs:

Mrs. Alora Powless of R.R. #5, Chatham has been in to see us concerning her daughter Muriel Stonefish. Mrs. Powless, who is the daughter of Christopher Stonefish, had her in the custody placed in the Mount Elgin Indian Residential School through the efforts of Mr. Stonefish and the aid of Miss Stonefish. We have attended the Residential School for some time. We believe and are informed that she did play truant from this school on at least two occasions, along with some other girls. This year the Principal of the Mount Elgin Indian Residential School, the Reverend G. B. Strapp, refused to allow Muriel Stonefish to return to his care for the summer holidays although the other girls had played truant along with her and returned to school. Mrs. Powless has asked us concerning the possibility of transferring her daughter to this school, which may or may not be possible at any rate she has been told by the conclusion that her daughter could not return to this school until she could attend school and be under her supervision. This is the desire of both Mrs. Powless and her father, Christopher Stonefish, who are living in Chatham in the Mount Elgin Indian Residential School. We want to know if they should be allowed to visit.

Dear Sir:

Attention Mr. R. A Hoey

I would acknowledge receipt of your letter 7-0-10 of Aug. 12th, also a copy of a letter received from Messrs. Wilson, Pike, Stewart & Lewis concerning Muriel Stonefish, a pupil of Mount Elgin Indian Residential School.

Muriel Stonefish according to the principal of the school is 15 years of age and at the time of her admission was resident with her grandfather, Christopher Stonefish of the Moravian Reserve, who had her placed in Mount Elgin School, where she has been for the past four years.

Muriel, who is an illegitimate child, did absent herself from the school during the past school term and when she was located by the police was in the home of her mother Mrs. Flora Powless at Chatham, Ont., which home the police considered nothing but a bawdy house.

Early in July of this year Christopher Stonefish, grandfather of this girl appeared at Mount Elgin School and at the request of the Principal was quite willing that she remain there again during the holiday period, as the grandfather claimed he would have no control over the girl if she returned to his home.

Mr. Strapp, Principal of Mount Elgin, informs me that this firm of solicitors had been in touch with him and also with Indian Agent Spence of the Moravian Reserve, to which Muriel belongs, and that both the Principal and Agent had instructed these solicitors that the girl was to remain in school because the grandfather and guardian was willing that she remain so. The legitimate claim put forward by Mrs. Powless would be detrimental to the girl if she was allowed from school in care of her mother.

Mr. Strapp contends that if this girl is removed from the school to the custody of her mother, that he does not wish her to return and that such removal would be contrary to the best interests of the girl.

If any further information is wanted in this case, I would suggest that you write Indian Agent Spence of the Moravian Reserve, as he would be quite familiar with the case and as Muriel is a member of that agency.

Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,

Gentlemen:

I desire to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 29th ultimo with reference to Muriel Stonefish, a pupil of the Mount Elgin Indian residential school.

At the time this girl was admitted to the Mount Elgin residential school she was residing with her grandfather, Christopher Stonefish of the Moravian Reserve.

Information that we received indicates that the mother's home is wholly unsatisfactory and if the girl were placed there the influences to which she would be subject would be demoralizing. In fact the principal of the Mount Elgin residential school would not be prepared to accept her if she were placed for a time under her mother's charge.

Taking everything into consideration the Department feels that it is in the best interests of Muriel Stonefish to remain in the Mount Elgin Indian residential school and we are not prepared to favourably consider either discharging her at the present time or allowing her holidays.

Gentlemen:

Your letter of the 12th instant, addressed to Mr. Philip Phelan of this Department, has been passed on to me for consideration and reply.

In reply to your inquiry I may state that Section 10, Subsection 1, of the Indian Act reads as follows:

"Every Indian child between the full ages of seven and sixteen years who is physically able shall attend such day, industrial or boarding school as may be designated by the Superintendent General for the full periods during which such school is open each year; provided that where it has been made to appear to the satisfaction of the Superintendent General that it would be detrimental to any particular Indian child to have it discharged from school on attaining the full age of sixteen years, the Superintendent General may direct that such child be detained at school for such further period as may seem to be advisable, but not beyond the full age of eighteen years, and in such case the provisions of this section with respect to truancy shall apply to such child and its parents, guardians or persons with whom such child resides during such further period of school attendance."

Yours truly,

Dear Doctor Stone;

I have to report that Doreen Powless, aged 16 years, a pupil at Mount Elgin Residential School, has been examined by me, and is believed to be pregnant. This girl, who is a member of the Oneida Band of Indians at this Agency, was brought to my attention by the Principal of the school on December 5th.

External examination strongly suggested a pregnancy, confirmed by questioning. The patient volunteered that the condition originated last August while she was at home on summer vacation. On December 5th I obtained a specimen of urine upon which a Friedman Test was done at the University of Western Ontario. This is reported as positive for pregnancy.

I have recommended to the Indian Agent and Principal of the school that this girl be discharged in care of her father, and arrangements are being made by them for this procedure.

Dear Sir:

I would like to acknowledge receipt of your letter dated February 17th, along with which was enclosed copy of a letter written to the Justice Department by Mr. and Mrs. Smith. It seems evident from this that there is an attempt to prevent the Indian Residential School from doing what should be done.

In conclusion, I would advise that I have discussed the matter with the Principal of the School and he informed me that they will not allow them to demand anything more. The R.C.M.P. were notified and through their efforts the girl was brought back to the School.

The girl, Emily Green, upon her return to the School, was questioned by the Principal as to why she ran away. It was immediately then made known to her that the reason she was sent to the School to study was so that she could be taught various kinds of things to make her more valuable to society in the future. Emily answered in a manner that left no doubt but it is believed that she had been stolen. However, when asked why she stole from the School girl to steal from younger children, she eventually reached some of the older girls at the School who in turn were very upset and ridiculed her to such an extent that she decided to run away. When she returned to the School in the evening, the R.C.M.P. were summoned immediately. The Principal of the School stated that she would not steal anything herself nor would she again ask younger pupils to steal for her.

The Principal of the School assured her that he was not in favour of imprisoning the girl as it would only encourage others to steal. She was then placed under the care of the Principal until further notice.

Your obedient servant,

- Nora Monague, daughter, aged 11
- Olive Monague, daughter, aged 9

The mother wishes to have her three daughters enrolled at residential school i.e., Audrey, Nora and Olive. These three girls have been attending the United Church Indian Day School at this Agency.
